column1: In de bacheloropleiding Fiscaal recht is bij het vak Formeel Belastingrecht stil gestaan bij de inleidende aspecten van formeel belastingrecht, zowel voor de directe als voor de indirecte belastingen. In het vak Formele aspecten van de indirecte belastingen wordt op een verdiepend niveau ingegaan op de formele aspecten van de diverse indirecte belastingen.

Het vak wordt onderwezen door middel van wekelijkse hoor- en werkcolleges waarbij het in die week centraal staande thema integraal wordt besproken. In de werkcolleges, die door vaste docenten worden aangeboden, wordt u in groepen getraind om aan de hand van casusposities de relevante formele aspecten te onderkennen en uit te werken.

Voorts zult u in duo’s of trio’s deelnemen aan de oefenrechtbank, waarbij elk duo/trio ofwel de rol van gemachtigde ofwel de rol van inspecteur aanneemt. De docenten zijn de rechter(s). U wordt getoetst op de formele aspecten die samenhangen met het procederen.

column1: <body>Na het volgen van dit vak is de student in staat om:

column2: • zelfstandig complexe vraagstukken op het gebied van indirecte belastingen vanuit formeelrechtelijk perspectief te analyseren en op te lossen;
• de uitgangspunten en fundamenten van het formeel belastingrecht – voor betrekking hebbend op indirecte belastingen – te benoemen, herkennen, onderscheiden en begrijpen;

• de samenhang en de verschillen te onderkennen tussen enerzijds formeel belastingrecht bij de indirecte belastingen waarvan de heffingsprocedure in de AWR is neergelegd en anderzijds formeel douanerecht;
• samen te werken met medestudenten op een fiscaal multidisciplinair terrein;
• te pleiten over een fiscaal-juridisch vraagstuk ten overstaan van medestudenten en in te spelen op de argumenten die de wederpartij aandraagt;
• zelfstandig een aangedragen fiscaaltechnische probleemstelling te analyseren, zich daarover een mening te vormen en deze te beargumenteren op een gedegen wetenschappelijke wijze;
• de analyse en argumentatie ten aanzien van een fiscaal juridisch vraagstuk begrijpelijk en overtuigend weer te geven in een verhandeling.

column1: Law and legal issues are deeply integrated in most facets of business. Our course introduces some of the core legal issues that managers commonly face. I have asked legal practitioners for input to guide the Core areas. In addition, there will be extra material available for those who want to Explore more topics. To help structure the course, we will be using a textbook that takes a management, rather than a purely legal, approach to different topics. In addition, to emphasize the RSM mission of being a force for change, we will be emphasizing the ethical areas where law is less clear and managers must navigate challenges and face uncertainty.

The focus of the course will be on US and UK legal language and the common law system. This motivation is very practical: the vast majority of international contracts draw on these systems, English is most often the preferred language in international business dealings, and we need a common platform as a starting point to illustrate issues and develop awareness. In reality, some grounding basics really help managers identify legal issue, communicate with legal teams, and trouble shoot a range of business-and-legal issues (Bagley, 2008). We will highlight some major differences in systems and contracts (and other legal documents) throughout the topics.

The ultimate goal of the course is for you to begin to develop an awareness of legal issues and to add legal insights to your business acumen. A deeper understanding of legal issues in business can create advantages among managers and firms, leading to value creation and protection (Bagely, 2008). We know that legally astute managers with the ability to use legal language and communicate with a basic understanding of law are more effective negotiators, have stronger contracts, and are even able access more affordable financing. In addition, these managers are able to better manage alternatives to courts and legal conflict (Pinkham & Peng, 2017).

column1: Management Consulting is for many business students a challenging yet rewarding profession. Rivalry within the industry is intense and client demands and expectations are high. Are you up for the challenge of becoming a successful management consultant? And what would you have to learn still, to kick-start a possible career in this competitive industry?

Consultants are important agents of organisational change, applying and transferring knowledge about business problems to advice and - increasingly - to assist managers to deal with such problems. Many business students will act as or deal with consultants sometime in their professional life. The purpose of this course is to introduce you to the consulting practice, the consulting industry and to develop your cognitive skills. This is done by explaining concepts and through close interaction and collaboration with professional consultants.
Also we will pay special attention to hypes in the consultancy world.</body>

-       Explaining the dynamics of the client-consultant relationship.
-       Identifying essential skills and knowledge for different types of consultants
-       Identifying the hypes and concepts of the current consultancy world

column1: This course provides an introduction into the foundations of (analytic) philosophy.
More in particular, we present a concise introduction to the foundational disciplines of logic, philosophy of language and epistemology.

This course is the replacement of Philosophy of Science 1 for students of our BA programme Philosophy of a Specific Discipline. If students already completed Philosophy of Science 1, they will not have to take Foundations of Philosophy.
Fulltime and parttime students will not take Foundations of Philosophy, but Philosophy of Science 1.

column1: 1. The student understands the basic concepts pertaining to informal and formal logic (propositional logic, a bit of predicate logic and a glimpse of modal logic).
2. The student is able to translate natural language arguments into a formal language and to use this translation to assess the validity of these arguments.

3. Understanding central concepts from the philosophy of language (meaning, reference, speech act, denoting phrase, modes of speech, intension vs extension), in order to understand the workings of language better.
4.  Understanding central concepts from epistemology (knowledge, belief, justification, knowledge sources, scepticism), in order to understand better knowledge claims and their justification.</body>

column1: This course provides an introduction to the origins and evolution of political economy theory, concepts and practice. Political Economy studies questions that straddle the relationship between the state, economy and society. The aim of this course is to introduce students to some of the foundational work in the fields of economics and politics and explore the main ideas developed in the analysis of the interconnectedness of state, market and society. To provide a coherent narrative to the students the course is structured chronologically, tackling important questions from the dawn of political economy to the urgent questions of the 21st century.

The course starts with a historical introduction to the field and its classical thinkers, before exploring in more depth the contemporary market-institutional perspective on three important issues of political economy: welfare, inequality, and sustainability. Rather than learning about the complete body of works of particular authors, we focus on big questions and the answers that different key thinkers brought to these specific questions.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Students who have successfully completed this course will be familiar with the development of the field of political economy and its relevance to urgent problems of the 21st century.  Students will learn about the main concepts and theories and how they are used in contemporary scholarship.  Students should be able to formulate questions on political economic issues, identify political economic components of current global issues, and assess critically the contributions that different (and at time opposite) approaches make to the understanding of political economy.
After the course students should be able to:

column2: • Situate the field of political economy in the social sciences: be able to explain what differentiates P.E. from political science, economics, philosophy and international relations, be able to explain what specific angle of analysis P.E. takes on past and contemporary issues.
• Be able to critically analyse the relationship between state, markets and society at different points in the history of capitalism.

• Provide an overview of some of the main ideas and concepts the field of political economy from the 18th century until the 21st century, specifically ideas and concepts from Smith, Ricardo, Marx, Mill, the Marginalists, Schumpeter, Keynes, Hayek, Friedman, the Neoliberals, and the Critical School.
• To be able to apply political economic thinking and analysis to contemporary problems, particularly globalization and trade, welfare, inequality and sustainability.

column1: This course takes a close look at the role and the status of the individual in the European Union. Throughout the course particular attention is paid to the theory of citizenship in the Marshallian sense, according to which citizenship has a civil, political and social dimension aiming at ‘full membership in a community’. Against this background, the course explains the concept of market citizenship and the meaning of individual rights in the context of furthering European economic integration. A special focus will be on the tensions between national rules restricting individual free movement and residence rights and European rules aiming at eliminating discriminations based on origin and market access restrictions. Within this context, the course addresses the theory and practice of fundamental (market) freedoms starting with the free movement of persons and the freedom of establishment, turning to the freedom to provide services, as the fundamental freedoms of individuals as market actors.

An important part of the course is dedicated to the most recent transformation of the role and status of the individual in the European Union: the establishment and development of the Union citizenship. The Union citizenship seemingly marks a qualitative leap as compared to market citizenship in that it creates supposedly an overarching legal-political status encompassing all nationals of EU Member States no matter their link with European economic integration. The course assesses the potential and the limits of the Union citizenship, including the relationship between EU citizenship and the ‘democratisation’ of the Union. It examines whether and to what extent the well-established solutions and findings from the market freedoms are transposed to the free movement rights of the Union citizens. It also sheds light on the often-complicated relationship between European non-economic free movement rights and national social law, as well as the access to social benefits. What is more, the course takes a forward-looking perspective, by inquiring into the immediate consequences and the wider potential implications of Brexit on the future development of EU citizenship.

Furthermore, the course looks into the legal treatment of third-country nationals wishing to migrate to the EU in comparison to that of EU citizens. Last but not least, it offers an all-embracing perspective on the legal treatment of individuals within the European Union, by examining their legal status in the context of the policies (Schengen and EU external border management, asylum and immigration, judicial cooperation in criminal matters) within the realm of the EU Area of Freedom, Security and Justice (AFSJ).
Lecture; seminar; workshop / Interactive and Problem-based learning (PBL) oriented teaching (in physical, full online or hybrid format depending on the Corona-related circumstances)

The course format combining interactive lectures and guest lectures with dedicated seminars and workshops stimulates active learning, critical thinking and group discussions. The mix of various assignments and activities throughout the course in the form of a mini-essay, case analyses, and other specific tasks enable students to acquire in-depth substantive knowledge and to bring their legal research-analytical skills to the next level.

The format of the lectures features interactive discussions of the relevant subject-matter (first half of the session) in combination with in-depth case analysis of one or two landmark judgments of the Court of Justice of the European Union (second half of the session).

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: As a result of this course, students should be able to:

•           Gain a consolidated understanding of the various dimensions and stages of the Union citizenship (learning objectives 4, 5, 6, 9)
•           Analyse and assess the political, economic and sociological rationale underlying the concept of citizenship in EU law (learning objectives 3, 5, 8)

•           Develop and conduct independently advanced academic research, provide and communicate, in writing as well as orally well-reasoned legal opinions on the subject-matter of the course (learning objectives 9, 11, 12)

column1: This course is part of cluster 1: Representation: Democracy, Science, and Culture.
Basic questions will always be helpful, so let us start with asking this:

The latter may perhaps sound strange but this will be the leading question for this course, nevertheless. If we think that people have a culture, we suggest it is not something that is embodied in them. We are probably thinking about culture, then, only in terms of representation. There are very good reasons to think about culture in such terms, for dominant building blocks of a culture are offered to people by means of texts, images, sounds, tastes, and so forth. Through these, culture, as Freud suggested, has an alienating force. It enforces itself from some sort of outside on people and shapes them in such a way they both coincide and no longer coincide with themselves. This is why cultural representations do not remain ‘out there’, at some sort of distance. They make people feel very affectively attached to their culture. Cultural representations, that is, are capable of organizing peoples’ minds and bodies, affectively. Still, we can do more justice to this by thinking about culture also in terms of its being a medium, or considering its forms of expression as mediatized. Here the issue is not how thing are represented but are always coming to us via a material medium. One such medium, and a dominant one, is language.

We start with Sigmund Freud and Giorgio Agamben to weigh against one another the alienating force in culture on the one hand and the formative force on the other hand. Both thinkers explore, explicitly or implicitly, what the relation is between culture and power. In this context we ask whether Agamben’s form-of-life is a concept that can help us to reconsider the relation between culture and power, or between culture and representation. We then proceed, in session 2, with assessing that cultures are not a matter of diversity or joyous expressions of different forms of life. Cultures imply struggle, internally and externally. They have been used to hierarchize relations between human beings and animals, and between human beings amongst one another. This has become most apparent in colonial, postcolonial and decolonial contexts, which is why we look at the work of Frantz Fanon and Gayatri Spivak. In session 3 we consider, if cultures are not simply something that people have but which they live, what consequences this has for people’s abilities to change things. This is not like saying that cultures have an unchangeable essence. There is only evidence that cultures change over time. There is also evidence that there are cultural elements that persist through time for thousands of years, just as there is evidence that people can be ‘caught in culture’. We will be helped by Raymond Williams and Judith Butler to assess the persistence and potential to change culture.

With session 4 we move to a different plane of analysis. Culture manifests itself on the basis of two definitions. One concerns the organization  of how people express their communal being, the other concerns the domain of aesthetics, in short: art. Perhaps the latter has dominated our thinking in terms of representation most severely. Here we will consider representation in terms of its producing an aesthetic breach between two spheres, in its potential to function rhetorically and poetically in the translation of culture. In session 5 we tune in on the potential in culture/art to rhetorically convince and to aesthetically affect. The two are not opposed to one another, but have a different intensity and function. The first can explain why people do things, the second captures why people find it difficult to explain why they live the way they do.

With session 6 and 7 we reach the third building block, in our focusing on mediation. To this order we first explore how culture has been considered in relation to playing or gaming. At the back of this is a massive study by Huizinga, Homo ludens from 1938, but since the latter’s analysis of culture in terms of play a lot has happened to the world and the way in which it is organized by media. We end in session 7 with looking at the concept of mediaton per se, how it difers from representation, and what the scope and potential of this concept are in relation to culture in the broader sense of the term and in terms of art.
In all session we will provoked to think by works of art that play an equally important role in shaping our thoughts as the theories addressed.

column1: This course is one of three thematic modules in the LDE Minor ‘Frugal Innovation for Sustainable Global Development’. It connects the modules on Technology and on Development, with a focus on how entrepreneurs see opportunities to use frugal technologies to develop new (frugal) business models, and it prepares the ground for the developmental implications of these entrepreneurial activities. An important thread running through the block is the importance of co-creation in frugal innovation, showing that successful entrepreneurs work more and more in flexible networks with people with complementary competences.

The course first introduces characteristics and motivations of different types of individual entrepreneurs. The second part identifies the external environment for entrepreneurs who want to become or are engaged in frugal innovation. We examine what types of value chains they are involved in, what are the requirements of serving distinct market segments like the Bottom of the Pyramid and the new middle classes, the role of the institutional and regulatory environment, and the importance of and challenges of compliance with quality and sustainability standards.

The final part of the block focuses on different business models for frugal innovation, competences required to achieve profitability and their prospective developmental implications, as a bridge to the third block on development, and as a way to enable students to practice applying the business canvas model to their prospective field assignment.

column2: Reproduce and interpret knowledge about frugal innovation from a technology perspective;

Learn from other disciplines, in particular innovation (management) and technology studies, and relate this knowledge to and integrate into their own disciplinary background, and

column1: This course is the first of the three thematic courses in the LDE Minor ‘Frugal Innovation for Sustainable Global Development’. Because students in this minor may not have a purely technological background, this course on Technology and Frugal Innovation will start from the point of view of innovation management by which students become more acquainted with innovation theories and how frugal innovation relates to an fits into these theories. From there the step is made to innovation for low resource or resource constrained settings, what do such settings imply for innovation and product development cycles, and the technologies involved. Students learn about Technology Readiness Levels, and develop answers to questions such as: what implications do different cultural contexts have for product design? What is frugal technology and how does it come about? And how can we use technology in a coordinated way to solve problems? We will join academic debates about, among other things, frugality, early commitment, value sensitive design, management of technology, and science, technology & innovation development, which focus on different forms of technological development.

After this two strategic themes are chosen to go more in-depth and to which general concepts and notions are applied: 1) medical diagnostics targeting good health and well-being (SDG 3) and 2) clean water and sanitation. The first strategic theme focuses on good health and well-being. Researchers at TU Delft work together with designers, doctors and local parties on integrated frugal solutions. The aim is to design radically new diagnostic equipment that optimally functions within the specific characteristics of local health systems. In the course will take on the challenge to adapt the developments of new medical equipment to the needs and requirements of local healthcare systems, through case driven education.

The second strategic theme is access to clean drinking water and sanitation. Access to clean drinking water is only one side of the coin, because the increasing degree of urbanization puts the natural hydrological cycle under great pressure. Discharge of municipal and industrial waste water increasingly threatens clean water reservoirs, which due to the growing water demand are already experiencing seasonal shortages in many areas in Southeast Asia and Sub-Saharan Africa. By means of practical cases students get acquainted with basic (frugal) concepts in water purification and hydrometry and/or weather forecasting. The connection with health is also discussed.

column1: This course is the third thematic module in the LDE Minor ‘Frugal Innovation for Sustainable Global Development’. Now that students have been introduced to the entrepreneurial and technological aspects of frugal innovation, they need to be made aware of the context in which these two aspects play. In the literature, it is often assumed that frugal can contribute to the improvement of the living conditions of poorer people and the realization of the SDGs, but whether this potential is also realized depends on many factors. This course has three main themes: the actors involved, local context analysis and measuring impact. During the course the field assignment will function as the real life case around which in-class and out-class assignments are organized.

Firstly, students get acquainted with academic debates about the access to and use of Frugal Innovations by different groups in society (male / female, old / young, poor / rich, etc.) and the differentiated effects of frugal innovations within society, both for users and for entrepreneurs. Issues of agency, power and inequality will be addressed, and will be linked to discussions in the previous courses on technology and entrepreneurship. This also provides further insights into the role of various actors in frugal innovation and their interaction (consumers, producers, entrepreneurs, politicians, policy makers, etc.).

Secondly, frugal Innovation arise from or come into being in a specific context, in which existing social, economic and political institutions have a major influence on the way in which frugal innovations take shape. Students learn about the interaction between different types of institutions and the establishment of frugal Innovations, and the effects and impact of these innovations on local, regional and international development processes.

Thirdly, attention is also paid to how you could measure the effects and impact of frugal innovations on local as well as regional or national development. This is a new field of study which needs rapid development. Students are introduced to current measuring models.

column1: The Frugal Innovation in Practice comprises of a field assignment which is conducted abroad during +/- 12 weeks. During their stay abroad students will work on a field assignment, which can be more research or more practically oriented. Students are divided into groups of three, ideally with one student from each participating university (Leiden, Delft, Erasmus). In this way, they bring together their knowledge base and integrate it with that of the others.

Field assignments will be arranged by the minor coordinators before students start with the minor, and will be allocated to students at the end of June 2019, before Summer holidays. This offers students the opportunity to contact field assignment providers and supervisors in an early stage to allow for proper preparation and arrangements. The field assignment to be allocated in June contains a general description and challenge. During the first part of the minor (Bootcamp, Field Assignment Preparation Course) the students will work themselves on making the field assignment more concrete, in collaboration with the assignment providers and the supervisors.

The students have to finance the internship (travel, accommodation and living costs) themselves, unless (part of) the costs is covered by the assignment providers. The costs involved during the stay abroad are to a large extent country and context specific but between 2,500 and 3,000 Euros is a realistic estimate of the costs involved. Students will be provided with suggestions on where to find opportunities to apply for subsidies.

In principle the field assignment will be abroad. In the previous academic year (2018-2019) field assignments were arranged in Uganda, Ghana, Cambodia, Surinam and Curacao. In the exceptional case that students do not want to do a field assignment abroad, the possibility for a field assignment in the Netherlands can be discussed. In such case students are requested to get into contact with the minor coordinator (Dr. André Leliveld, a.h.m.leliveld@asc.leidenuniv.nl) as soon as possible after they have been selected for the minor.

column1: Practicing journalism in a globalized world involves navigating through various cultural environments and poses a number of challenges to journalists, who have to manage their values and those of their audiences on one hand, and those of the people in the countries from/about which they report, on the other hand. In many cases, what appears to be a key moral principle in one country might end up being a trivial issue in another place. What is held to be a fundamental legal or ethical responsibility in one country’s journalistic tradition, might be a small, neglected detail in another country’s journalistic tradition. The advent and steady development of new technologies have only exacerbated these concerns, since online journalism contents are potentially accessible anywhere, regardless of geographic boundaries that used to define who consumed which contents. This seminar introduces students to the tenets of journalism in international settings, by closely scrutinizing how those tenets apply to key practices in journalism such as interviewing, selecting news subjects and taking them through the gatekeeping process. The seminar has both theoretical and practical components: The theoretical component explores the fundamental tenets of international journalism and, by means of essays and in-class discussions, invites and encourages students to reflect on the cultural, ethical, and legal aspects that underlie journalistic practices in a digital society. The practical component encourages students to be in the shoes of international correspondents and to produce journalistic items for a foreign audience, while reflecting on potential cultural, ethical, and legal challenges.
Note: The maximum number of participants to these course is 25. IBCoM students take priority over other students.

column1: The International Business law course is an introduction to the major issues in Business Transactions and Corporate Law from a global perspective. The first part of the course concentrates on the sources  of  international business  law.  Any  such  global  or  transnational perspective  begins  with  self - regulation i.e., the way the international business community itself tackles legal problems and uncertainties that are related to increasing globalisation. Furthermore, governments also recognise the need for adequate rules for international commercial transactions and operations in concluding international conventions or other instruments aimed at unifying, harmonising or co-coordinating their national laws. However, large areas of Business Law have not been touched by self-regulation or by uniform Law and are governed by national Law. The second part of the course looks at institutional choices for doing cross-border business. Direct transactions, sales representatives, commercial agency and distributorship and franchising are discussed. This part continues with  corporate law issues in cross border dealings and  discusses branch offices, subsidiaries and joint ventures. In this respect different business forms are  analysed including factors bearing on choice of organization, including partnership attributes, process of corporate formation, corporate privileges and powers, corporate capital structure, limited liability, management, control. The third part of the course introduces students to international business transactions ranging from barter and counter trade, sales, construction and service contracts. Aspects of intellectual property law including licensing law are also covered. It also looks to international payments and finance, secured transactions, insolvency and insurance (including export credit insurance).

The course will discuss the arbitral process starting from the agreement to arbitrate until the enforcement of arbitral awards. It will cover both contractual and procedural aspects of this arbitral process.

column1: Voor een succesvolle onderneming is het van groot belang dat zij kan inspelen op veranderende (markt)omstandigheden en haar juridische structuur kan aanpassen als dat wenselijk of noodzakelijk is. Het vak Fusies, reorganisaties en insolventie (RB41) gaat over de aanpassing van de juridische en financiële structuur van vennootschappen en ondernemingen en over degenen die daarbij zijn betrokken.

Allereerst wordt aandacht besteed aan manieren om ondernemingen samen te voegen of te splitsen via een overname, fusie of splitsing. Omdat veel overnames worden verricht door private equity fondsen, wordt het onderwerp overnames mede vanuit het perspectief van private equity belicht. Ook het economische aspect van overnames komt aan bod met de behandeling van waardering van ondernemingen.

Werknemers worden veelal geraakt door fusies en overnames. Ook als sprake is van financiële moeilijkheden, raakt dit in veel gevallen de positie van werknemers. Werknemers hebben daarom medezeggenschapsrechten. Ook worden zij beschermd bij een overgang van onderneming op basis van Europeesrechtelijke regels, die zijn geïmplementeerd in Boek 7 BW. Tot slot kunnen werknemers slechts worden ontslagen wegens bedrijfseconomische omstandigheden indien is voldaan aan de daarvoor gestelde voorwaarden. Onder meer deze arbeidsrechtelijke aspecten worden in het vak behandeld.

Als een reorganisatie mislukt, blijft het mogelijk dat een onderneming blijft bestaan. De verwachting is dat de Wet homologatie onderhands akkoord (WHOA) op korte termijn in werking treedt. Met deze wettelijke regeling kunnen vennootschappen hun schulden herstructureren. Lukt het niet om buiten faillissement tot een oplossing te komen met schuldeisers, dan kan een vennootschap failliet worden verklaard. In faillissement kan, al dan niet door middel van een pre-pack, een doorstart worden bewerkstelligd. Op die manier blijft de onderneming voortbestaan. Diverse aspecten van het insolventierecht, waaronder het faillissement, de doorstart en de WHOA, komen tijdens het vak aan bod.
Al deze onderwerpen worden in samenhang behandeld tijdens dit vak. Het vak is verdeeld in drie blokken. Elk blok is gewijd aan een specifiek thema.
A. De verschillende soorten fusies, met aandacht voor de internationale aspecten, splitsing en private equity passeren de revue.

B. Dit blok ziet op de rol van de werknemer bij herstructurering en reorganisatie van de onderneming, met onder meer aandacht voor de rechtsgevolgen van een overgang van onderneming, medezeggenschapsrechten van de werknemers en ontslag wegens bedrijfseconomische omstandigheden.

C. Centraal staat het faillissementsrecht, waarbij gekeken wordt naar de verschillende actoren die hierbij een rol spelen. Daarbij kan worden gedacht aan de failliet, de schuldeisers, de rechter-commissaris en de curator. Ook wordt stilgestaan bij diverse manieren van reorganiseren van een onderneming door middel van een insolventieprocedure.

Het onderwijs vereist een actieve deelname van studenten. Naast hoorcolleges zijn er praktijkcolleges die worden verzorgd door praktijkjuristen. Ook dient u een gesprek/discussie op niveau (een tutorial) te voeren met een docent en medestudenten over een onderwerp dat valt binnen de reikwijdte van het vak.

EdTech (educational technology) is the combination of IT tools and education practices aimed at facilitating and enhancing learning. The exponential growth in technology has opened new ways of teaching and learning,  from robots making it easier to stay engaged to AI tools to assist teachers with grading, EdTech is in the  classroom and it is here to stay.
ErasmusX is a driving force behind educational innovation for the EUR. In co-creation with students we want to crack to the code of future-proofing education with EdTech.

This interdisciplinairy minor introduces students to the world of EdTech and offers students an opportunity to prototype and design their own EdTech solutions for EUR. The aim is to design and develop an IT tool with classroom teaching to create a more engaging, inclusive and personalized learning experience. Small teams  of students are challenged to find existing problems at EUR and prototype and design a solution for these problems. The best solution will be developped in co-creation with extrenal stakeholders.

While working on the prototypes is a team effort, students will be working on their 21st century skills proficiency as well. All students are individually asked to determine the skills they want to develop while participating in the minor, making the minor a personalized learning experience for all participants.

During the minor several EdTech professionals will host activities and share their hands on experience with the students. The 21st century skills development is encouraged through frequent meet-ups and lectures. Students receive guidance, coaching and a growth hack training from EUR academics.

column1: GBS students have the opportunity to do a practical research internship at an organization (minimum of 168 hours) and replacing an elective course. Any elective block may be selected.

The company-based project should seek to contribute to the knowledge of a practitioner, e.g. a manager or policy officer within an organization. Important aspect is that the practitioner should need the developed knowledge to act upon. The research should not be related to the thesis, UNLESS it can be proven that the work done for the thesis would not have been possible without the research internship (CBRP). It must be clear that the CBRP is a separate project that cannot be used as an integral part of the thesis, is can only be used as input for a separate analysis for the thesis.

If a student opts for a Company-based Research Project one of the electives can be substituted which counts for 6 ECTS. This will give them the opportunity to work exclusively within the company for a period of 7 weeks. Research internships may be agreed for a longer period of time, but a minimum of 168 hours is expected and a maximum of 6 ECTS is credited. A list of available Company-Based Projects can be found through RSM Career Services or occasionally directly through the professors. Students are also welcome to contact companies directly.

column1: GIS for urban research is a hands-on practical learning course in which participants will learn the application of GIS toolsin social sciences research. The course will start with an elementary introduction to GIS, followed by a general overview of spatial analysis tools. On the third day, participants will choose a topic for their individual assignment (from a pre designed set of spatial research problems). The major portion of the course will be on creating GIS databases and getting basic skills in geoprocessing data. There will be guest lectures on advanced spatial analysis tools and methods ((optional). Furthermore, one session will be dedicated to showing how spatial research can be used to better plan and manage cities.

Participants will work on an individual task throughout the course, with the support from small peer working groups. Peer support and individual consultations will assist participants in fulfilling the assignment. At the end of the course, participants will hand in their assignment; a selection of participants will be invited to present their work to the other participants on final day of the course. Furthermore, assistance will be provided to the participants in finding online help and tutorials in order to continue developing their GIS skills independently (even after the end of the course).

column1: GMAT staat voor Graduate Management Admission Test. Heb je hulp nodig bij het kwantitatieve deel van de GMAT? Heb je de GMAT nodig voor je toelating tot (bijvoorbeeld een pre-master) IBA van de RSM? En wil je je ook graag richten op het aanleren van een examenstrategie voor het kwantitatieve deel? Het LTC helpt je graag op weg!
Wat leer je tijdens de GMAT training?

Het Language & Training Centre verzorgt een speciale online GMAT wiskunde training. De training bestaat uit een online lespakket en 4 face-to-face bijeenkomsten waarmee je wordt voorbereid op het wiskundige (kwantitatieve) gedeelte van de GMAT. Het einddoel van de training is: alle wiskundestof beheersen die je nodig hebt voor de GMAT! Dus inclusief examenstrategieën en een heleboel oefening met ""echte"" opgaven!

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: De studiebelasting van deze training is 4 x 2 lesuren plus zelfstudie en vergt veel tijd en inzet: vóór aanvang van de training ga je namelijk aan de slag met het online oefenprogramma. Tijdens en na de training werk je daarmee verder. Daarnaast krijg je speciale opdrachten om vertrouwd te raken met typische GMAT-vragen en maak je veel originele GMAT-opgaven om ervaring op te doen voor het examen. Hoeveel uren je daar precies in moet investeren, varieert en hangt sterk af van je niveau.
Wanneer je 2 maanden na de laatste les al een examen wilt doen, moet je rekening houden met een studiebelasting van minimaal 15 uur per week vanaf de dag van je inschrijving.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Het internationale GMAT examen bestaat uit 4 onderdelen: 'an analytical writing assessment', 'integrated reasoning', 'a quantitative section' and 'a verbal section'.
• We gaan er van uit dat je bij aanvang van de training bekend bent met de opzet en de eisen van de GMAT. Klik hier voor de officiele website van het GMAT examen.

• Deze training wordt in principe in het Engels gegeven. Indien wij merken dat de groep bestaat uit enkel Nederlandssprekende deelnemers, dan zal de training (gedeeltelijk) in het Nederlands gegeven worden.
• In 'the verbal part' van het GMAT examen wordt behoorlijk diep getest of je goed Engels beheerst. Om die reden dien je redelijk tot goed Engels te beheersen.

• Je krijgt de beschikking over een online zelfstudiepakket ALEKS dat je de mogelijkheid biedt om je wiskundige basiskennis en je algebraïsche vaardigheden in kaart te brengen. Vervolgens biedt dit digitale leersysteem je een op maat gesneden training aan waarmee je je de ontbrekende GMAT-onderdelen eigen kunt maken. Dit systeem is 24/7 beschikbaar en je kunt alle onderdelen net zo vaak oefenen totdat je ze beheerst! Indien de training doorgaat ontvang je de bevestigingsbrief en de inlogcode voor dit programma, ongeveer twee weken voor de start van de cursus via e-mail. We raden je aan om direct met ALEKS te starten.

<li>Het studiemateriaal is gedeeltelijk bij de prijs inbegrepen. De hand-outs, de syllabus en het online programma ALEKS zijn bij de prijs inbegrepen. Het boek niet, en daarom is het noodzakelijk om één van de volgende edities aan te schaffen:

column1: In many industries, the people – or the Human Resources – are the vital factors shaping success or failure for organizations. Decisions that involve the hiring, training, job assignments, and retention (or dismissal!) of employees have far-reaching consequences. These consequences do not only involve financial gains, losses, or potential legal implications for the organization, but also affect individuals and their motivation and ability to be productive and satisfied.

This course offers you an evidence-based perspective on the main challenges in Human Resource Management (HRM). We begin by examining the conceptual foundations of HRM, including the design of jobs and work processes, and the conditions under which work is satisfying and engaging. We then focus on the hiring process all the way from human resource planning to sealing the deal with new hires and starting the socialisation process. Building on this, we deal with how one can achieve great results with the people within an organization by motivating and rewarding their efforts, measuring their performance, as well as training and developing them for current and future tasks. Finally, we will consider how to manage employees’ voluntary and involuntary exit from organizations.

By the end of the course, you will have a deep understanding of and basic hands-on experience with the most important HR practices in light of empirical evidence that supports or discourages their use.  You will have learned to look beyond short-term financial gains for the organization when making decisions that affect people in organizations, but also have a thorough understanding of evidence-based guidelines on employee well-being, job satisfaction, and fairness. As a result, you are able to use your knowledge and skills about HRM to be a force for positive change for peoples’ working lives.

Given that HRM is a central organizational function, this course has links to many other courses in your curriculum. It particularly builds on your first-year course Organisational Behaviour, which laid the foundation for many of the concepts we will apply to workplace settings in this course and sets the stage for the third year specialism for People Experts.

• Apply HR-related knowledge and skills to solve real-world organizational challenges in an international context and as a team.
• Develop an evidence-based mindset in reflecting on the role of evidence in guiding the actions of people managers.

column1: In the course of modernization, traditional role models of gender and sexuality have been traded   in for a system in which all people have the freedom to do what they want. Or have they? In this course, students will acquaint themselves with the main manifestations of the contemporary landscape of Gender and Sexuality Studies as well as their historical and theoretical underpinnings, so as to be able to distinguish fact from fiction from the opening sentence. We will learn that far from being “women’s issues”, ideas of gender and sexuality are fundamental to how post-industrial societies are structured, and hence, important for everyone to understand.

We will address questions like: How do nature and culture matter for feminist and queer theorists? What are the boundaries of the public and the private? What do masculinities have to do with social change? Is multiculturalism harmful for women? Why is the relationship between bodies, desires, and identities so contentious?

This course will trace the arch of Gender and Sexuality Studies by focusing on the following social institutions: 1) family, 2) work, 3) state, and 4) media. In traversing this field, we will try to make sense of some prominent controversies in the contemporary world: from bans on burqas and transgender rights, to the Me Too movement and surrogacy.

column4: <td>
Introduction

Gender is a constitutive aspect of how we make, understand, experience and research cities. Gendered assumptions and power relations not only shape the production and experience of urban space and inequalities but also the ways in which we ask questions and conduct research about cities. Gender, however, has been at the margins of urban theory, practice, and research which reinforces gendered inequalities that mark the contemporary urban world.

This course is designed for participants who want to learn why gender matters for urban managers and how to make plans, policies and research gender-sensitive. It enables participants to think critically about gender representations and power relations and examines intersections between gender relations within the socio-economic and spatial processes in cities.
Course Content
The course is composed of  three modules:

1. Gender in Urban Theory offers a selection of contemporary gendered/feminist debates in urban theory to deepen students’ understanding of cities as gendered spaces and the production of gendered geographies of (in) justice.

2. Gender in Urban Practice (Planning and Policy) presents feminism’s contributions to planning theory, and debates how gender plays out in urban policy and planning. During this module, practical toolkits and guidelines for planning and policy analysis will be presented.

3. Gender in Urban Research introduces key principles and guidelines of how to engage in gender-sensitive research practice. By questioning conventional approaches to research, the participants will learn how to apply feminist approaches to different research methods (such as in-depth interview, focus groups discussions, and survey) to gather both qualitative and quantitative data and to conduct gender analysis

• Critically assess urban policies, plans, and research from a gender perspective
• Apply gender-sensitive research methods and feminist approach to research
• Convincingly communicate ideas and arguments related to gender and urban development

column1: The course will start by defining what ‘life’ actually is, and how different life forms (organisms) can be characterised and distinguished. Specifically, the general structure of viruses, prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells will be discussed. We will zoom into the various classes of biomolecules and the way in which they are produced and metabolised within living cells. Subsequently, we will discuss the fundamentals of DNA replication, the genetic code, transcription (RNA synthesis) and translation (protein synthesis). Then, we will move on to study cell division (mitosis and meiosis) and genetics. Finally, we will study the most vital aspects of the physiology of higher animals and plants.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

- have a fundamental knowledge of the structures and functions of the most important molecules of life: nucleic acids, proteins, polysaccharides and lipids;
- be familiar with genetics, the genetic code, the functions of, and differences between, DNA and RNA;
- understand the principles of messenger RNA production and protein synthesis;
- have an understanding of the basic structure as well as metabolism of cells and organisms.

column1: Some of the topics that will be considered during this course are evolution of the human brain, development of language and reading, and the biology of behaviour. We will overlay these fundamental properties with discussions on disorders such as autism spectrum and other developmental disorders, unipolar and bipolar mood disorders, schizophrenia, and drug/alcohol addiction. Moreover, topics such as gene therapy, genetic screening, and personalised genomics will also be covered. As we consider these scientific and medical matters, we will discuss the societal debates they foreshadowed. For example, gene-editing technology and whole-genome sequencing might soon become the reality of prenatal diagnosis of genetic disorders. How will society respond to those new technologies and will they also be used to address disorders of the brain, which often have complex etiology. Finally, the knowledge of the complete sequence of the human genome (and that of other species) provides both new opportunities and new issues regarding disease risks, confidentiality, the conduct of research, and evolution.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After taking this course the students will be able to:

column2: • Be acquainted with new research approaches and technologies in neuroscience, understand what their applicability is, and how they broaden our understanding of the human brain;
• Know the basics of how genes can regulate neuronal function and communication within and between neuronal networks;
• Grasp the importance of responsible science communication and how knowledge of biological basics of human behavior can affect law and policy making;
• Understand critical periods in the brain development and how genetics and environmental influences can shape this process;
• Have a fundamental knowledge of how genetics guide our behavior, how in return behavior can regulate genetics and what the societal implications of research in this area are;
• Describe what is known about early life acquisition of language; how reading skills develop and what the most likely causes of language disorders such as stuttering and dyslexia are;

• Understand phenotypic variation in autism spectrum disorder, be able to discuss leading theories about its causes, characterize neuropathology in ASD at anatomical and functional level and have a fundamental knowledge of diagnostic and therapeutic tools available to people with ASD;
• Be familiar with other developmental disorder such as Angelman and Fragile X Syndrome, identify the genetic causes of those syndromes and briefly describe undergoing research to find treatments;

• Describe known genetic and neurophysiological factors which increase the risk for mood disorders and be able to discuss how societal perception of people suffering from those maladies changed over the last few decades;
• Have a fundamental knowledge of the frequency, epidemiology and heritability of drug addiction and abuse, and understand the role of dopaminergic pathways and reward-learning in those behaviours;

column1: The course provides an overview of state-of-the-art methods that are used to study the genetic contributions to differences between people and how these genetic insights can be used in the social sciences.

After decades of scientific debate, a consensus has emerged that all human behavioral traits are partly heritable (i.e. they are affected to some degree by random genetic variation within families). Integrating genetic data into social-scientific research opens up new possibilities to (i) control for factors that are otherwise unobservable, (ii) to increase the statistical power of empirical analyses by absorbing residual variance in multiple regression analyses, (iii) to study the interactions of genetic factors and environmental exposures, (iv) to use random genetic differences among people to identify causal pathways, and (v) to better understand how social (dis)advantages are transferred across generations and how parents, peers, teachers, and policy makers can potentially alleviate or intensify such (dis)advantages.

Collecting genetic data is now feasible at high speed and high accuracy at low costs. Thus, the time is now ripe to integrate genetic data into social-scientific research, benefitting from these recent technological developments and scientific break-throughs.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Students will become aware of the relevance of genetic factors for human behavior and socio-economic outcomes. After the course, students will be familiar with state-of-the-art statistical methods that play an important role in genetic discovery studies. This includes genome-wide association, linkage disequilibrium (LD) score regression, and genomic-relatedness-matrix restricted maximum likelihood (GREML) estimation.
Furthermore, students will learn how to construct polygenic scores, how to use them in social-scientific research, and how to interpret the findings from genetically-informed empirical studies.
Finally, students will learn programming skills in PLINK and UNIX that will enable them to work with large genetic datasets.

column4: Hoe kinderen opgroeien, hoe ze onderwijs krijgen, hoe ouders dienen op te voeden, hoe leerkrachten zouden moeten onderwijzen: het lijken vandaag de dag vanzelfsprekendheden. Kinderen worden in kleine gezinnen door hun ouders met liefde en grenzen opgevoed, geleid door principes van rust, reinheid en regelmaat; een pedagogische tik is daarbij uit den boze. Op school krijgen kinderen onderwijs in klassen van 25 leerlingen van dezelfde leeftijd en wordt er niet meer gedisciplineerd met de plak of liniaal. Maar hoe hebben deze ‘vanzelf-sprekendheden’ zich ontwikkeld? En waarom is de vanzelfsprekendheid van opvoeding en onderwijs niet universeel? In andere culturen gelden andere normen, in andere tijden golden die ook. En soms zijn huidige ideeën niet zo nieuw als wij denken dat ze zijn.

Ideeën over opvoeding en onderwijs ontwikkelen zich al met al niet in een cultureel-historisch vacuüm. Vaak zijn huidige ideeën geworteld in een lange (Europese) traditie. Het is daarom voor pedagogen en onderwijskundigen van groot belang een beeld te hebben hoe deze ideeën zich sinds de Middeleeuwen hebben ontwikkeld.

In dit blok maken studenten kennis met de geschiedenis en de onderlinge wisselwerking van pedagogische ideeën en pedagogische praktijken. Aan bod komen de meest invloedrijke pedagogische scholen vanaf 1500 en de sindsdien gehanteerde concepten in de praktijk van opvoeden, zorg en onderwijs aan kinderen en jongvolwassenen. Centraal daarbij staat steeds de tijd- en plaatsgebondenheid van pedagogische en onderwijskundige ideeën.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

De geschiedenis van het denken over het sociale mondt in de moderne tijd uit in het ontstaan van de sociologie als academische discipline. Sociologie is een term die begin 19e eeuw door Auguste Comte (1798-1857) werd bedacht. Vervolgens is er veel werk verzet door bijvoorbeeld Du Bois (1868-1963), Durkheim (1858-1917), Weber (1864-1920) en Simmel (1858-1918) om te bepalen wat sociologie is en hoe het als wetenschappelijke discipline beoefend moet worden. Het is daarbij de canoniserende werking van het sociologisch veld geweest dat ook Marx (1818-1883) werd opgenomen als klassiek socioloog. In dit vak bespreken we het “ontstaan van de sociologie”. De belangrijkste vraag die aan de basis van deze cursus ligt is: Bij welke denkers vindt de hedendaagse sociologie haar disciplinaire idealen, welke ideeën zijn daarbij cruciaal gebleken en hoe verhouden die zich tot de wereld waarin deze denkers leefden?

De cursus bouwt daarmee voort op het vak Inleiding van de Sociologie. Daarin komen vragen naar stratificatie, sociale cohesie, modernisering en identiteit naar voren als vier hoofdvragen van de sociologie. In dit vak zullen de problemen die bij de tutorgroepen aan de orde komen ook voor een groot deel op die hoofdvragen gericht zijn. Die vragen hebben namelijk hun historische context in onder meer de ontwikkeling van het moderne, industriële kapitalisme en in de opkomst van de moderne samenleving. Specifieke historische processen maken zo inzichtelijk waarom ongelijkheid, cohesie, modernisering en identiteitsvorming zo prominent aanwezig zijn in de sociologie.

Bij dit vak is het van belang kritisch te leren lezen. De problemen bestaan uit citaten van ‘klassieke’ sociologen, en het is de bedoeling dat je die citaten als student goed uitpluist met behulp van de primaire en secundaire literatuur die in de bibliotheek te vinden is, plus enkele aanvullende teksten. Begrip van de teksten waarin de gebruikte citaten voorkomen, is een vereiste om het tentamen voor dit vak succesvol af te ronden. Het is ook een voorwaarde voor de mogelijkheid op een theoretisch geïnformeerde manier te kijken naar de sociale werkelijkheid. Tenslotte is dit begrip van belang omdat in het veld van de sociologie voortdurend expliciet of impliciet verwezen wordt naar het werk van o.a. Comte, Marx, Du Bois, Durkheim, Weber en Simmel en het is dus cruciaal voor sociologen om daar weet van te hebben.

Paleografie is volgens de definitie van Van Dale de wetenschap die studie maakt van het oude schrift. In de loop der eeuwen is de schrijfwijze van het Nederlands en andere talen aan verandering onderhevig geweest. Die zijn zo groot dat geschriften van een aantal generaties terug al moeilijk te lezen zijn. Het kunnen lezen van oud schrift is daarom een essentiële vaardigheid voor historici die zich met de geschiedenis van voor de negentiende eeuw bezighouden maar scherpt ook de leesvaardigheid van onderzoekers van negentiende en twintigste-eeuwse bronnen.

In dit college zal de ontwik­keling van het schrift worden bestudeerd binnen het kader van meer algemene ontwikkelingen op cultureel en sociaal gebied. Enerzijds wordt het lezen van oude teksten in de praktijk geoefend. Anderzijds wordt via de voorgeschreven literatuur de context van de ontwikkeling van het schrift bestudeerd. Tevens wordt aandacht geschonken aan de betekenisverandering van van Nederlandse woorden. Woorden en zinsbouw zijn namelijk altijd aan verandering onder­hevig en taalgebruik is cultureel en dus ook historisch bepaald en gebonden aan klassen en sociale groepen.

Thema's die aan de orde komen zijn onder meer: alfabetisering, de invloed van de drukpers, de samenhang tussen schrijven en lezen en tussen verschriftelij­king en staatsvorming, de ontwikkeling van de brief als commu­nica­tiemiddel en verschillen tussen pu­bliek en privé schrijven. Twee excursies maken deel uit van het college.

column1: Welkom bij het vak Geschiedenis van het Privaatrecht! Dit vak is met ingang van het academisch jaar 2020-2021 in een nieuw jasje gestoken en behandelt de beperking van aansprakelijkheid in verschillende historische perioden, met het accent op handels- en ondernemingsrecht.

Allereerst komt het Romeinse recht aan de orde. Handelsactiviteiten werden in de hogere Romeinse kringen eigenlijk als ‘not done’ beschouwd, maar de mogelijkheid om er inkomsten mee te verwerven bleek in de praktijk toch te aantrekkelijk. Veelal liet een Romeinse pater familias de uitvoering over aan slaven of ondergeschikten. Aan de hand van (vertaalde) teksten uit het Corpus Iuris Civilis zal worden nagegaan hoe zijn aansprakelijkheid in dat kader gestalte kreeg. Voor delicten van slaven was hij ten volle aansprakelijk, zij het dat hij kon volstaan met het uitleveren van de slaaf aan de gelaedeerde; voor door slaven gesloten contracten was hij slechts aansprakelijk voor zover hij hun een peculium (werk­vermogen) had toegekend of tot de hoogte van zijn uit het contract voortgevloeide verrijking. Ook kon hij optreden als financier achter een (meestal, maar niet per definitie) vrije institor (filiaalhouder), of als exercitor(reder) van een schip, bestuurd door een magister navis (schipper). Een interessante vraag daarbij is in hoeverre deze rechtsfiguren in het latere recht gerecipieerd zijn.

Na de instorting van het Westelijk deel van het Romeinse rijk krijgt de handel in Europa vanaf circa 1100 nieuwe impulsen dankzij technische vooruitgang in de scheepvaart. Handelssteden en -netwerken komen op die hun macht en welvaart vooral danken aan hun overzeese handelsverbindingen met andere steden. Daarvoor zijn schepen nodig en ook toen al was veel kapitaal nodig om schepen te laten bouwen. Daarbij deed zich echter het probleem voor dat scheepvaart weliswaar zeer lucratief kan zijn maar tevens grote gevaren en financiële risico’s met zich meebrengt. In een tijd dat er nog geen andere alternatieven bestonden om de risico’s verbonden aan scheepvaart in te dammen ontwikkelde zich geleidelijk de gedachte aan een scheiding tussen het zeevermogen (fortune de mer) en het landvermogen (fortune de terre) van een scheepseigenaar. Via rechtsfiguren als de rederij, de comman-ditaire vennootschap, het abandon van schip en vracht, het executie- en het fondsenstelsel kreeg het leerstuk van de beperking van aansprakelijkheid van de scheepseigenaar gestalte. Hoewel omstreden heeft deze bijzonderheid van het zee- en binnenvaartrecht zich tot de dag van vandaag weten te handhaven.

De kapitaalvennootschap wordt wel beschouwd als een van de instituties die een cruciale bijdrage hebben geleverd aan de westerse economische ontwikke­ling in de afgelopen eeuwen. De BV heet niet voor niets voluit besloten vennootschap met beperkte aansprakelijkheid. De beperkte aansprakelijkheid maakte het mogelijk om kapitaal aan te trekken waarmee ondernemerschap werd bevorderd. Aan de hand van het thema beperkte aansprakelijkheid van aandeelhouders en bestuurders onderzoeken we de geschiedenis van de kapitaalvennootschap die begon bij de oprichting van de VOC in 1602. Welke gevaren zag de wetgever van het Wetboek van Koophandel van 1838 in deze rechtsvorm? Hoe is het leerstuk van bestuurdersaansprakelijkheid ontstaan? Wat is de ratio van de beperkte aansprakelijkheid en wat zijn haar gevaren? Deze vragen worden behandeld in historisch perspectief en in hun actualiteit.

column4: In het practicum Gespreksvaardigheden I maakt de student kennis met effectief communiceren in professionele gesprekken in de beroepspraktijk van universitair geschoolde pedagogen en onderwijskundigen. De student leert een aantal basale gespreksvaardigheden die nodig zijn voor professionele gesprekken. Het gaat hier vooral om vaardigheden in de eerste fase van een hulpverleningsgesprek, met als doel probleemverheldering. Met behulp van speciale computerprogramma’s (VIP’s) maken studenten kennis met verschillende vaardigheden, zoals verbaal volgen, concretiseren en vragen stellen. In ‘live’ bijeenkomsten worden deze vaardigheden geoefend in rollenspellen en andere oefeningen. De student voert hierbij professionele gesprekken met een medestudent (in de rol van cliënt), in aanwezigheid van een student-observant.

Het practicum wordt afgesloten met een rollenspel waarin de student een professioneel gesprek voert met een cliënt over een pedagogische vraag of probleem. De cliënt wordt gespeeld wordt door een staflid van Pedagogische Wetenschappen. Dit rollenspel vormt de basis voor beoordeling van de gespreksvaardigheden van de student.

column1: In daily and business life, you can find yourself in situations where you want to get something done, but you do not have much to offer as an exchange. For example, you want to initiate a project or business, but you are lacking cash, knowledge and resources. You may have an idea for a great new product, but your superiors are only supportive when it takes a limited investment and no excessive risks. Or you want to expand your network with some highly-regarded people, potential employers or difficult to approach customers for your own business, but those people may not find you very interesting. These situations are in a basic sense similar to all ‘ventures’ where success depends on your ability to mobilize other people and to reduce risks. Entrepreneurial bootstrapping is the pursuit of success (or getting things done) with limited resources and with the help of others (or free outside help). In general, bootstrapping refers to a self-starting and self-sustaining process that is supposed to proceed without external help or input. The origins of the term seemingly go back to the 19th century American in the phrase ‘to pull oneself over a fence by one’s bootstraps’ , to mean carrying out an absurdly impossible task.
After the kick-off class where the phenomenon of bootstrapping will be introduced, the course includes 8 plenary lectures, in which five subthemes of bootstrapping are distinguished and discussed.

-    Principles of bootstrapping (lectures 2, 4, 6 and 8): the four basic principles of bootstrapping will be introduced: informal and creative resource acquisition, the use of networks, networking and influencing skills, entrepreneurial marketing (marketing on a shoestring) and entrepreneurial finance (do more with less).

-    Creative resource acquisition strategies (lecture 3): in one perspective bootstrapping is an original strategy of obtaining resources without a big spending effort, for instance through a direct exchange of goods and/or services with others without money (barter trade) or by making creative use of the limited resources one has at its disposal (e,g. effectuation, frugal innovation and bricolage).

-    Networking (lecture 5): Networking is at the heart of any bootstrapping effort. Lectures will first cover networking theory, i.e. the purposes and potential effects of networking, and how networking partners can be a source of free information and advice. We then proceed with more specific networking skills on how to get in touch and build a relationship, and subsequently, how to influence other people and/or benefit from ‘relevant others’, such as friends, family members, mentors and coaches.

-    Entrepreneurial marketing (lecture 7): Here we will explore the emerging phenomena of innovation by users, open-source projects, and crowdsourcing. User innovation basically implies that there are many users out there who develop their own products to use themselves – and they generally share their innovations for free! Open-source projects imply that a distributed community of users contributes to an overall project. Crowdsourcing, finally, is the act of outsourcing tasks to an undefined, large group of people or community through an open call, implying that you can mobilize people to work for you.

-    Entrepreneurial finance (lecture 9): financial bootstrapping refers to the different strategies entrepreneurs pursue to keep the venture under their control (not diluting all kinds of bootstrapping techniques involving cheap ownership and equity in the company), turning key fixed costs into variable costs, or by effectively managing cash flows and making process within the firm efficient. The entrepreneurial finance approach will be elaborated by considering money and crowdfunding.</body>

column1: The aim of this course is to study and expand the theory of bootstrapping, and to apply bootstrapping techniques in practice. On the basis of proven theories and relevant research, this course will offer you practical and workable tips that require little or no money and where and how to get support for free, advice, and consulting, to help you to make any project more likely to succeed. At the end of the course, students should be able to:
•    identify how bootstrapping projects differs from traditional ways to plan and finance your projects/ventures;

•    understand and evaluate the main bootstrapping techniques, including networking, barter trade, free outside solutions, frugal innovation, open source resources, mobilizing crowds, cheap finance, and entrepreneurial marketing;
•    practice with these techniques in real-life situations;
•    to develop a pro-active and entrepreneurial mind-set (e.g. taking initiatives and making their own judgments);

•    to show effective presentation and writing skills in the creation of teaching cases and/or field reports (e.g. business plan, consultancy report, checklist/roadmap) that have value for the stakeholders involved and/or a larger audience;</body>

column1: De ontwikkeling van het kind vormt de basis van het werk van pedagogen, waarbij de vraag “hoe zorg ik ervoor dat een kind zich zo optimaal mogelijk kan ontwikkelen?” centraal staat. Welk type opvoeding is het beste voor een kind? Hoe werkt opvoeden bij ouders met een verstandelijke beperking? Wat is de invloed van leeftijdgenoten op de ontwikkeling en het gedrag van kinderen? De gezinspedagogiek bestudeert de ontwikkeling en opvoeding van kinderen en daarbij behorende opvoedvragen van ouders. Pedagogische vraagstukken over onder andere het nature-nurture-debat, adoptie, kinderopvang, kindermishandeling en opvoedstijlen worden behandeld in deze minor. De theoretische basis voor het bestuderen van de context waarin het kind opgroeit wordt gevormd door het sociaalecologische model van Bronfenbrenner waarbij het kind zich ontwikkelt in interactie met zijn omgeving: bijvoorbeeld ouders, school en kinderopvang en leeftijdgenoten.

Naast de opvoeding in verschillende contexten, worden gezinnen in verschillende contexten bestudeerd. Het gezin anno 2019 kent veel meer verschijningsvormen dan het traditionele kerngezin (vader, moeder en hun kinderen). In deze minor zullen we allereerst de verschillende wijzen waarop een gezin gevormd kan worden bestuderen. Hierbij kunnen we enerzijds gezinnen onderscheiden waarbij de manier waarop het gezin gevormd wordt niet-traditioneel is (bijv. adoptie, pleegzorg of IVF) en anderzijds gezinnen waarbij de betrokken ouders zelf niet aan het traditionele beeld voldoen (bijv. homo-ouders of tienermoeders). Het gaat hierbij dus om niet-traditionele gezinsvormen. Daarnaast kan ook de samenstelling van het gezin soms niet-traditioneel genoemd worden. Tegenwoordig wordt het traditionele kerngezin vaak voorgesteld als een vader, een moeder en twee kinderen. Gezinnen met meer dan drie of vier kinderen zijn bijzonder, maar ook een gezin met één kind zou niet-traditioneel genoemd kunnen worden. Tot slot kunnen er zich in de loop der jaren ook ontwikkelingen voordoen in gezinnen (bijv. echtscheiding of overlijden van een ouder) waardoor niet-traditionele gezinnen ontstaan (bijv. eenoudergezinnen of samengestelde gezinnen). Het niet-traditionele gezin kent dus vele gezichten. Hoe vaak komen deze verschillende gezinsvormen en gezinssamenstellingen eigenlijk voor? Welke gevolgen heeft dit voor de ontwikkeling van het kind in deze gezinnen? Welke gevolgen heeft dit voor het ouderschap en het welzijn van de ouder? Is er ondersteuning nodig bij deze gezinnen en is die ondersteuning effectief? In deze minor wordt een antwoord op deze vragen geformuleerd.

In de minor Gezinnen van nu worden alledaagse opvoedthema’s bestudeerd vanuit een wetenschappelijk perspectief. Kennis over en ervaring in statistiek en het bestuderen van Engelse-talige (review)artikelen is een pre, maar geen vereiste. De gebruikte didactiek is probleemgestuurd onderwijs (PGO), waarbij de (verplichte) kleinschalige onderwijsgroepen (2x per week) de kern vormen van het onderwijs. Colleges zijn verdiepend of verbredend en worden facultatief aangeboden. Studenten die onze minor met succes afronden en voldoen aan de Methoden en Technieken/SPSS-eis kunnen na het behalen van hun WO Bachelor (Sociale Wetenschappen of aanverwante richting) rechtstreeks instromen in de Master Gezinspedagogiek: Opvoeding in de hedendaagse samenleving. column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: De gezinspedagogiek bestudeert de opvoeding van kinderen met een normale ontwikkeling en de daarbij behorende opvoedingsvragen van ouders. Hierbij richt de gezinspedagogiek zich op opvoeding in gezinnen. De klassieke definitie van ‘het gezin als duurzame samenlevingsgemeenschap van een man en een vrouw met de uit hun verbintenis voortgekomen kinderen’ (Vandemeulebroecke, Van Crombrugge & Gerris, 1999, p.14) is hierbij echter te smal. Adoptiegezinnen, eenoudergezinnen, gezinnen van homo-ouders en vele andere soorten gezinnen vallen buiten deze definitie. Binnen de gezinspedagogiek wordt dan ook gepleit voor een brede definitie van het gezin.

Het gezin anno nu kent veel meer verschijningsvormen dan het traditionele kerngezin (vader, moeder en hun kinderen). In dit blok zullen we allereerst de verschillende wijzen waarop een gezin gevormd kan worden bestuderen. Hierbij kunnen we enerzijds gezinnen onderscheiden waarbij de manier waarop het gezin gevormd wordt niet-traditioneel is (bijv. adoptie, pleegzorg of IVF) en anderzijds gezinnen waarbij de betrokken ouders zelf niet aan het traditionele beeld voldoen (bijv. homo-ouders of tienermoeders). Het gaat hierbij dus om niet-traditionele gezinsvormen. Daarnaast kan ook de samenstelling van het gezin soms niet-traditioneel genoemd worden. Tegenwoordig wordt het traditionele kerngezin vaak voorgesteld als een vader, een moeder en twee kinderen. Gezinnen met meer dan drie of vier kinderen zijn bijzonder, maar ook een gezin met één kind zou niet-traditioneel genoemd kunnen worden. Tot slot kunnen er zich in de loop der jaren ook ontwikkelingen voordoen in gezinnen (bijv. echtscheiding of overlijden van een ouder) waardoor niet-traditionele gezinnen ontstaan (bijv. eenoudergezinnen of samengestelde gezinnen).

Het niet-traditionele gezin kent dus vele gezichten. Hoe vaak komen deze verschillende gezinsvormen en gezinssamenstellingen eigenlijk voor? Welke gevolgen heeft dit voor de ontwikkeling van het kind in deze gezinnen? Welke gevolgen heeft dit voor het ouderschap en het welzijn van de ouder? Is er ondersteuning nodig bij deze gezinnen en is die ondersteuning effectief?
