Recht ordent. Dat gebeurt door regels, beginselen en rechterlijke uitspraken. Gezondheidsrecht is een gebied binnen het algemene recht met eigen karaktertrekken. Sterker dan in andere gebieden spelen grondrechten een rol, zoals privacy en lichamelijke integriteit. Daarnaast kenmerkt het gezondheidsrecht door de aandacht voor de patiënt. Om het gezondheidsrecht te begrijpen is basiskennis van het algemene recht noodzakelijk, zoals de diverse algemene rechtsgebieden. Denk aan bestuursrecht, privaatrecht grondrechten en internationaal recht. Het gezondheidsrecht kent zijn eigen wetgeving inzake rechten van de patiënt, financiering van de zorg, kwaliteit van zorg en de verantwoordelijkheid voor bepaalde zorg en maatschappelijke ondersteuning. Daar wordt in dit vak op ingegaan.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>Doel van dit vak is basale kennis van de algemene rechtsgebieden die voor het gezondheidsrecht van belang zijn, alsook kennis van het specifieke gezondheidsrecht.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/94092,2020,Gezondheidsstrafrecht,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,['A.P. den Exter', 'D Eijpe, LL.B', 'mr. S Salverda', 'mr.dr.drs. L Postma', 'prof.mr. PAM Mevis', 'prof.mr.dr. MAJM Buijsen']",,"Inhoud

Het gezondheidsrecht is het functioneel rechtsgebied dat zich met de inrichting en het goed functioneren van de gezondheidszorg bezighoudt. Het is als zodanig van grote maatschappelijke waarde. Voor dat goed functioneren van de gezondheidszorg wordt in toenemende mate en via een steeds groter wordende diversiteit van thema’s ook een beroep gedaan op het strafrecht. Veel wetten op het gebied van de gezondheidszorg (inzake medicijnengebruik, orgaandonatie, etc.) bevatten strafbepalingen. Voorts kan het begaan van strafbare feiten door werkers in de gezondheidszorg (BIG-geregistreerden) het vertrouwen in de gezondheidszorg aantasten. Niet voor niets bevatten de artikelen 96 en 96a Wet BIG eigen strafbare feiten ter voorkoming van de benadeling van de gezondheidszorg alsmede een eigen regeling om een werker in de gezondheidszorg uit het beroep te ontzetten. Belangrijker is de toenemende roep naar strafrechtelijke aansprakelijkheid (of ten minste onderzoek daarna) in geval er bij medische missers sprake is van een calamiteit in de zin van de WKKGz, hetgeen al snel ook het vermoeden van een strafbaar feit zal impliceren. Dan komt bij onderzoek al snel de vraag op naar de strafrechtelijke positie van de betrokkene/arts, al dan niet in verhouding tot de instelling (ziekenhuis als verdachte) en dan is ook het medisch beroepsgeheim en verschoningsrecht in het geding. In de strafvordering is het recht van de patiënt op onderzoek erkend als een dringende reden op basis waarvan het verschoningsrecht in het opsporingsonderzoek moet wijken. Dat verschoningsrecht staat sowieso onder druk. Zo onder andere in het bredere beleidsdossier tot het vergroten van de mogelijkheden om ‘ fraude in de zorg’ te bestrijden.

Twee terreinen kunnen nog in het bijzonder nader worden genoemd. Dat is in de eerste plaats de bescherming van de openbare orde en veiligheid tegen (verwarde) personen die al of niet een strafbaar feit hebben begaan. Door de WvGGZ en de Wfz zijn per 1 januari 2020 hoge verwachtingen gewekt met en hoge eisen gesteld aan een betere afstemming van zorg en dwang ter zake. Het andere bijzondere thema betreft het strafrecht en indringende vragen betreffende het begin en het einde van het leven. Zoals bekend, bestaat in Nederland een regeling waarbinnen uitsluitend de arts onder strikte voorwaarde euthanasie of hulp bij zelfdoding mag verrichten, inclusief euthanasie bij ernstig gehandicapte pasgeborenen. De hele regeling wordt via het strafrecht gecontroleerd. Alle maatschappelijke controverses verdienen ruim aandacht in dit vak.

De uitbreiding van de betekenis van het strafrecht wordt geïllustreerd door het feit dat binnen het OM een Expertisecentrum Medische Zaken (EMZ) is ingericht. Dat zal zich in voorkomende gevallen van strafrechtelijke rechtshandhaving ook over de verhouding met het medisch tuchtrecht moeten buigen.

Binnen het gezondheidsrecht en de gezondheidszorg zijn de raakvlakken met verschillende aspecten van het strafrecht de laatste jaren in snel tempo geïntensiveerd. Doel van het vak is het verwerven van kennis van en grondig inzicht in de (toegenomen) betekenis van het strafrecht voor de gezondheidszorg aan de hand van actuele vraagstukken:

column2: • Inzicht in de raakvlakken tussen het strafrecht en het gezondheidsrecht
• Inzicht in typische strafbepalingen van de gezondheidszorg, zoals art. 96 Wet op de beroepen in de individuele gezondheidszorg (BIG)
• Inzicht in het strafrecht als controlesysteem binnen de reguliere en alternatieve gezondheidszorg mede in verhouding tot de wet kwaliteit, klachten en geschillen zorg (Wkkgz)
• Inzicht in de wezenlijke samenhang van het strafrecht bij medisch handelen bij begin en einde van het leven
• Kennis van de bijzondere positie van de arts als verschoningsgerechtigde en het ziekenhuis als rechtspersoon
• Kennis van de bijzondere positie van de gezondheidszorg in detentie

The course Global and European Governance provides an introduction governance beyond nation-states. The first part of the course introduces students into the study of international politics, with special attention to the role of international institutions and regionalism. The tutorials will focus on applying the lessons from the lectures to the particular policy questions at hand.

In the second part, students will concentrate on the European Union. The European Union is the most advanced instance of international cooperation in the history of humankind. The course will focus on the main institutional aspects of the European Union, economic integration as well on political integration, and the role of the EU in the world. We will also discuss the rise of Euroscepticism. The tutorials focus on analyzing EU policies, discuss Euroscepticism, and model EU bargaining.

column1: Technological advances and global market expansion require marketers, advertisers and communicators to develop an understanding of the developments and factors influencing their field. An increasing number of Western companies are looking to compete in non-western markets as the saturated markets in their own country offer only limited opportunity for growth. In this course, students will explore how a variety of companies target customers in different cultures and how they attempt to make educated decisions with respect to research, strategy, media, implementation and evaluation in today's globalized marketplace. Students will analyze and reflect upon different approaches that companies are using to communicate with diverse audiences across the globe.

Drawing on various communication models, students will analyze and interpret current advertising messages and issues arising from the creation and distribution of such messages in other countries in  a variety of different media.
Note: The course will be cancelled if there are less than 10 students. The maximum number of participants is 75. IBCoM students take priority over other students.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Current theoretical perspectives and research methods in the field of global advertising;
• The environmental factors affecting global advertising, including the impact of culture, regulation, and competition;
• The variety of advertising strategies and tactics used in the international arena.
• Critically review current research on global advertising and its uses in the advertising world;
• Collaborate with peers in order to analyze, reflect and present real-life cases in global advertising.

column1: The ultimate challenges of global advertising are about preserving a balance between the culture of the brand and the culture of the consumers. In practice, many companies use standardized advertising strategies and tactics across the globe (i.e., use identical headlines and visuals in different countries). Although the practice of standardization reduces the costs of global advertising, it may also limit its appeal and effectiveness. Standardization, therefore, is highly debated in theory.

In the research workshop Global Advertising, students will first be familiarized with theoretical and empirical literature on the acceptance and use of standardized and localized advertising strategies around the world. Next, students join forces and design and conduct an online experiment to gain an active understanding on the role of consumers’ perceived cultural similarity in global advertising effectiveness.

The research workshop Global Advertising enables students to gain hand-on experience in conducting and describing quantitative research. Two meetings are SPSS-sessions, actively guiding students through the data analysis and interpretation phase. Various sub assignments (related to the introduction, theory, method, and results sections) build up to the final product, which is a complete scientific report of 5,000 words. Students get detailed feedback on the sub assignments, allowing them to improve their work.
Note: Working experience with SPSS is desirable, but not compulsory.

column1: This Master course is primarily aimed at understanding the global strategic and corporate perspective of sustainability issues. The course focuses on the global issues that affect, and are affected, by business. While the first core course provided deeper insight in particular on worldwide (ecological) issues, this second core course considers the international business and international management side more directly – so in particular social and economic sustainability issues will also be taken into account. Global issues are portrayed as the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). They will take a more prominent role in this course. Moving abroad and managing across borders can be a very profitable exercise for firms. It, however, is also surrounded by considerable risks. This course focuses on the logic behind the strategies of multinational corporations (MNCs) in order to assess the strengths and weaknesses of particular strategies, and the management of international operations.  How do, or can, MNCs manage across borders, and what determines their performance? What motives are relevant and how can intentions become realities? Beyond a focus on profitability, we consider broader performance implications in how MNCs either contain negative reputation effects that stem from their operations, or develop a positive image due to the way they handle the manifold issues appearing in front of them, from handling corrupt regimes and dealing with currency instability, to developing solutions for major issues like poverty, neglected diseases, catastrophes or hunger.</body>

column1: International development is a heavily contested field. Some argue that corruption in the developing world is the main reason for countries staying poor, while others point to continuing colonial relationships in the form of exploitation of the environment and labour in poor countries, tax agreements with these countries that benefit multinational companies, and/or illicit capital flows. Similarly, there is debate on what the most effective development strategies are and on what external actors can do to alleviate poverty. This course aims to provide students with the knowledge and tools to meaningfully participate in these debates. Students get insights in the history of development as well as a thorough knowledge of the theories and debates on causes of economic growth, development and structural transformation, and on the role of human development, institutions, and culture in development. Next to these classical themes, there will be attention for the management of the global challenge of poverty and inequality. This means that issues like sustainable development, the Sustainable Development Goals, the role of foreign aid and of local policies will also be dealt with. The course has a strong empirical emphasis, providing insights in different indicators for development, poverty and inequality and working with available databases.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>After successfully completing this course, you are able to:

column2: • Assess the multiple causes for the growth and stagnation of countries: economic, (international) politics- and policy-related, institutional, and cultural;
• Evaluate the main theories on effective and inclusive development strategies and the main historical experiences with development strategies

• Evaluate the opportunities and limitations of international and national responses to global poverty and (gender) inequality, in particular the Sustainable Development Goals, foreign aid, and national social policies in developing countries;
• Evaluate indicators for assessing development, poverty and (gender) inequality

column1: The assertion that global politics is undergoing dramatic change has become a truism. The objective of this course is to understand and contexualise that change. We will critically analyse whether institutions and practices developed during an era in which states were the dominant actors in world politics are able to cope with today’s myriad challenges. How does global politics work in an increasingly interdependent world? Are the institutions of diplomacy and multilateralism equipped to cope with 21st century challenges that are set to change the world profoundly?

The course engages with what is being described as the 'post-Western moment' in global politics. The Western-dominated global political order is increasingly being challenged by 'new' actors, as well as new issues that are making their presence felt on the global stage: corporations, cities, individuals and other non-state entities.

Key questions that structure this course are centred on global governance: the structure problems that require a global political approach and the practices and structures that address them, the reality of which is rapidly and profoundly changing. Topics range from new forms and innovations in diplomacy as it relates to issues such as multilateralism, geo-economics, security, global cities and climate change, but also the nature of the evolving global order.

column1: In the developing world, millions of people have no, or limited access to urgently needed health care. Universal access to essential health care is an important but elusive goal. Many poor households are exposed to great financial risks related to ill health, or are forced to forego essential treatments altogether. The World Health Organization has once again put universal health coverage (UHC) high on the policy agenda and the United Nations have embraced the UHC as one of the targets of the Sustainable Development Goals.

Generally, to make progress on the path towards UHC, policy makers in low and middle income countries (LMICs) are required to raise more money for health, to move away from direct payments at the point of use and to use resources for health more efficiently and equitably. This course aims to provide students with a better understanding of each of these three topics and furthermore to evaluate specific health care reforms on this path towards UHC.

The lectures mostly consist of case studies, presenting evidence on health coverage extensions across the developing world. While the course is not focused on teaching new quantitative methods, the sessions do emphasize how the effectiveness of UHC reforms can be evaluated quantitatively.

Global history is the story of interaction. Mankind has engaged in migration and trade since time immemorial. Over the centuries, the different continents, religions and nations have interacted with one another through the exchange of money, goods, information and world views. On the one hand, these contacts may lead to the fusion and mutual influencing of cultures; on the other, they also lead to clashes. Indeed, war, colonisation and decolonisation mark the boundaries of interaction and exchange. In these situations, people have a heightened awareness of what makes their own group ‘unique’. This is yet another age-old phenomenon.

In this series of lectures and tutorials students learn how to structure and periodize Global History into a number of major periods. Discussing these periods, the students become familiar with concepts such as mercantilism, European expansion, colonisation, decolonisation, the postcolonial world and globalisation. Throughout the course, we reflect on the major themes and key developments of human history. Using a variety of case studies and primary sources, the course establishes connections between global developments and their outcomes at the local level.

<body>Students are introduced to the history of the world from 1500 to the present. At the end of the course the students are able to reflect on periodization in global history. They use concepts such as Eurocentrism, colonization, capitalism, resistance, decolonization, post-colonial world and globalisation. Students learn searching and finding primary and secondary sources in the library and use them in a meaningful way in independently written essays.</body>

The contact between individuals and organizations from different countries, cultures, and social groups has never been greater than in our time. In recent decades organizations have continuously globalized their operations, resulting in increasing frequency with which employees interact with colleagues and customers from different cultural backgrounds and ethnicities. At the same time, as a result of legal, social and economic shifts, workforce participation rates of women, minorities, and disabled people have dramatically grown, thus turning diversity into a strategic issue in organizations. Further, as executives operate around broader regions, global teams are formed to address the need to become globally competitive, and customers and suppliers operate across borders, the demands on global executives are ever growing.

This course is designed to help participants develop a deeper understanding of the issues that confront global managers today, and to prepare them for leadership roles in international organizations. Through business cases, experiential exercises, and real-life examples, the course strives to explore knowledge in leading diverse people as well as in leading global organizations. Emphasis will be placed on gaining awareness for the role of culture in organizations and on developing skills to manage diversity.

Each session is a module addressing a particular leadership challenge facing executives in the global arena (e.g., leading a diverse team, managing change, etc.). The teaching approach will vary, with a mix of lecture input, group discussion, case analysis, experiential exercises, and guest lectures.

column1: International, transnational and domestic actors shape and contest the global regulations and practices we live by. For example, the World Health Organization (WHO), which remains the primary organization involved in global health, provided guidance during the outbreak of Coronavirus. Moreover, the interaction between the WHO, states in the Global South, development aid donors and pharmaceutical companies affects access of millions of people to affordable medicine by regulating production and sales of so-called ‘generic drugs’. Ultimately, international regulatory regimes are an attempt to bring order to anarchy, make sense out of complexity and establish rules and predictability in at least some global policy areas. However, the practice of implementing these global rules is often confusing and contradictory. For instance, anti-money- laundering legislation initiated by the G7 has found higher compliance rates in ‘developing

countries’ than in OECD countries. In cases of high-level corruption, it is often NGOs and activist groups which elicit compliance, not the governments who signed anti-corruption legislation. These observations make one ask how we can achieve accountable and effective governance on global and local scales.

This course analyses the interaction -both formal and informal - between the different stakeholders (governments, business corporations, civil society representatives etc.) in the development and functioning of international regulations regimes. Amongst a variety of issues, students will address issues related to the production of generic medicine (TRIPS), fighting money-laundering and tax- evasion as well as bringing transparency to arms trade. Doing so, we challenge the simplistic assumption that global regulatory regimes always transfer most effective and best applicable practices. By going beyond legal aspects, international economics and a focus on international organisations or state actors, this course provides an expansion to the POLIR and EUC curriculum. Students will explore practical issues of global politics in commerce and health to understand how implementation and compliance challenges power asymmetries and international arrangements on a daily basis.

column1: How can firms gain and sustain their competitive advantage in increasingly competitive environment? Firms have realized that a focal source of competitive advantage lies in internationalization. At the same time, they have realized that increasing internationalization also bears challenges by exposing firms to competition from domestic as well as foreign firms. Furthermore, there are three factors that complicate the management beyond a firm’s domestic market: First, the potentially fundamental differences of markets, second, the scale and complexity of cross-border business, and third, the uncertainty revolving around the economic and political conditions between countries. In this elective, we will address these factors and their implications for firms’ competitive advantages in international markets and their considerations to move into foreign markets on the one hand, as well as for firms’ decisions regarding how they intend to operate across borders on the other hand. This will help us understand global strategy, why some firms thrive, while similar ones may struggle in the global marketplace.

The course consists of five sessions; it leverages academic articles and practical cases to develop students’ abilities to analyze global strategy issues. Students will have the opportunity to demonstrate their understanding of core concepts in weekly quizzes and class discussions.

Four of the online course sessions will be dedicated to specific aspects of global strategy. Each of these sessions consists of three parts. First, we will have a “mini-lecture” about one focal aspect of global strategy that concludes with one question or case scenario. Second, you will work in groups to resolve the question or case scenario. Third, we will discuss your solutions and wrap-up with a Q&A.

In one of our sessions, there will be a guest speaker from Vodafone. This person will talk about its professional experience working as a manager in a multinational firm. In this session, students will have the chance to reflect on the practical applicability and relevance of the academic articles, which they are exposed to as part of this course. Finally, students will end the course with a group project – and a video presentation thereof being due after one week after the final course session.

You are graded for your group project (report and presentation) as a group. The report of your project is to be prepared and submitted as a group, while not all group members have to present in the video. Managing the project and (dividing) related tasks is at each group’s own discretion.

Interactive discussions during our online sessions and group work are important parts of the course format. Active participation in class is required, but not graded. Our sessions serve to discuss the readings and their insights, as well as support you in working on your group projects. Attendance is not mandatory (at least not for this year), but please note that non-attendance is never an excuse for missing something. Please consult your fellow students to recover anything you may have missed during class.

I strive to evaluate all available information to arrive at a final grade that fairly reflects the student’s demonstrated capability in dealing with and understanding the course content. Evidence of this capability is recorded in this course through quizzes and a blog entry based on assigned readings, and a final group project based on assigned readings and project-related research. column1: From coffee to cellphones, the production and exchange of goods and services has never been more interconnected and dynamic than it is today. The liberalization and deregulation of international trade and investment, alongside IT development, have greatly contributed to the globalization and consequent fragmentation of production and consumption processes throughout countries. The pressure on companies to take their social responsibility –beyond their primary suppliers - has increased. Companies are increasingly viewed as responsible for sustainability and resilience both within the organization as well as in its wider ecosystem of suppliers and customers. In this course we explore the history and drivers of global value chain development and the role of companies in this process.

Global value chains and value chain approaches are perceived to fulfil an essential role in realizing the SDGs. Value chain approaches, including governance, integration and upgrading, have become important instruments for various stakeholders throughout the globe to create win-win linkages among value chain participants to increase efficiency and scale, enhance value-chain performance, and promote market-based development. Entry into global value chains is perceived to allow small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to participate in and reap the fruits of the global economy. During the course we will learn to understand a global value chain approach and analyse the role of various actors alongside companies, including international organizations and governments, in global value chains.

Despite the promising role of global value chains in spurring (local) development, their positive impact is not uncontested. How the benefits of value chain participation are distributed depends to a large extent on the conditions under which different actors interact. Participation in global value chains may lead to erosion of labour welfare and breakdown in social cohesion. Global trade spurs transportation, pollution and waste generation, thereby contributing to environmental degradation. There is furthermore the risk of widening economic gaps between countries, while global value chain participation might increase an economy’s vulnerability to external shocks. And although value chain participation has the potential to spur local development, Bottom-of-the-Pyramid (BoP) inclusion is by no means guaranteed. During the course we therefore critically analyze global value chain approaches as ways forward to achieve sustainability and local development.

‘Global value chains and local development’ focuses on explaining the historical development and key characteristics of global value chains, mapping different types of value chains and what this means for lead companies as ‘agents of change’, and understanding value chain approaches including governance and upgrading. Furthermore, during the course we will critically analyze the impact for different players, including stimulating economic growth, improving industry competitiveness, and realizing local development.

This course is offered to you by the Partnerships Resource Centre (PrC), a specialist research centre at Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University. The PrC has the objective to connect science and practice. Linking theoretical knowledge to practical problems, experiences and phenomena is therefore one of the key principles of this course.

column1: Supply chain management (SCM) has emerged as one of the major areas for companies to gain a competitive edge. Managing supply chains is a complex and challenging task, due to current business trends of expanding product variety, short product life cycles, increasing outsourcing, globalization of business, and continuous advances in information technology. Supply chain management, as a natural successor to operations management, is a fundamental driver not only for further improving operations but also for strengthening the competitive position of firms. When a company faces the pressure of excessive inventories, degraded customer service, escalating costs and declining profits, or a poor return on assets, its supply chain is out of control. On the other hand, when a company moves into new markets or new technologies, it must have its supply chain prepared for new business challenges and opportunities. The course will introduce students to concepts and techniques related to the design, management and improvement of supply chains and supply chain operations.

The course focuses on a variety of challenging supply chain business situations.  For example, how different types of supply contracts can be used to design win-win solutions between buyer and supplier, how the benefits of information sharing can be estimated in the context of supply chain, and what supply chain strategies match with proliferating product variety. Other topics include, but are not limited to, inventory management, supply chain transportation and distribution network design, operational hedging and global supply chain risk management.</body>

column1: ‘Globalization I: Culture & Society’ intends to introduce the phenomenon of globalization, and how it affects modern societies. This course will give you an opportunity to explore how various facets of globalization impact the world we live in today.

This course starts with recognizing how globalization affects the world around us. We then continue with looking at how globalization influences social identities. What defines our identity, who are we? We will then turn to the social media, and the ways how they transform the world around us. Then, we continue by looking at migration as an essentially globalizing phenomenon. In addition to immaterial culture, globalization very fundamentally affects also material culture – and we will analyze this process. We close by looking at how globalization influences the men and women in the world.

By the end of the course, you will understand that all culture is deeply affected by globalization – beyond what you would expect when you first enter the classroom. But is it all rosy? Never too far from real world, the contents of this course will touch on most of the topics that animate the debates in 2020.</body>

‘Globalization: Economy & Politics’ will give you an opportunity to explore how globalization impacts on local conditions, as well as how governments cope with the globalizations’ impact.

The course starts where the course ‘Globalization: Culture & Society’ left off. We begin with a discussion of economic globalization. Why do businesses move to countries with lower production costs, and with what consequences for all involved? We then continue with the discussion of poverty and inequality, drawing on both local cases and evidence from across the world. Does globalization make inequality increase, or does it help societies to cope with it?

Governments frequently try to manage the challenges through international cooperation. What have been the patterns and why is it so? What are the consequences for states, as well as for the international institutions? How do such institutions work?

By the end of the course, you will understand how the pressures on corporate boards in New York influence real livelihoods in Africa. You will be also able to explain why some international organizations adopt decisions in very clumsy way.

<body>After an introduction on trade before the industrial revolution, the relation between increased specialisation, industrialisation and the growth of economic contacts will be discussed. In the second half of the 19th century, monetary stability and free trade created a truly global economy, but not without suppressing a substantial part of the  world. From 1914 on, two world wars and the Cold War prevented a complete recovery of economic relations. Political interests caused that national economies were created with relatively limited international contacts. In post-1945 Europe this was a problem. Not only had the 1930s shown that economic nationalism was fatal for growth and development, but Germany also was a problem. For these reasons European economic integration seemed a solution. Until the collapse of the Soviet Union, this proved very successful. In the 1990s liberalisation of international markets, but also, just as in the late 19th century, an enormous decline of transport costs, caused a second period of globalisation. Now multinational companies cut apart their production chains,  and each step was done wherever in the world is cheapest. Europe was no longer the centre and its process of integration, that after the Cold War got a boost, is now even crumbling.</body>

column1: The course starts with two general lectures on the question why we should be engaged with international and comparative research in criminology; how with the process of globalisation a so-called ‘global criminology’ has emerged; and point at some socio-historical and cultural factors that have determined why criminology developed differently in Europe, North America, Latin America and Africa. The key-question in this respect is whether concrete criminological questions can actually be addressed with theoretical models that pretend to have a global validity, but mostly have Western biases. Next we will follow the structure of Katja Franko her book, of which the central line is that globalisation and digitalization offers opportunities for certain people and indeed confronts others with new limitations and forms of social exclusion.  Globalisation and digitalisation also come along with types of crime and deviance that take place across physical and digital borders. In this context, we deal with human trafficking, cybercrime, eco-crime and crimes against humanity. Additional readings offer a more concrete analysis of each of these issues, whereas guest-lecturers and practitioners will bridge the academic and the practical dimensions of the issues discussed.

In this course, we will discuss theories and empirical cases related to the contemporary functioning of art worlds and the dynamics of cultural globalisation and aesthetic appropriation which shape them. Arguably, cultural production and consumption have become more transnationally-oriented. We look at the changing relationship between cultural production and consumption and place; the networked nature of artistic production and consumption, and the social conventions that govern them. Students get acquainted with the major contemporary trends and developments in the visual arts, music and the media, drawing on case studies from Western and non-Western context.  This course will be conducted as seminar which foregrounds student discussion and analysis of the readings.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>This course aims to take a fresh look at the notion of art worlds and the socialized nature of artistic and cultural production and consumption à la Becker, in light of theories of and empirical research on cultural globalisation. Drawing on examples from contemporary art movements, the media and music industries from around the world, we look at how art worlds operate across spatial scales; and how trends and social conventions spread across the world; and how they become embedded in different places and social contexts.</body>

column1: Central to the seminar is cultural globalization: the global dispersion of (popular) cultural products. Cultural exchange transcending regions and nation-states is not a new phenomenon, but the past three decades witnessed an accelerated intensification of international cultural flows, thanks to much improved dissemination means (e.g. streaming and other digital technologies) and  transnationalisation in media and cultural-industry businesses.

Media are pivotal in this process of cultural globalization: all around the world, people are familiar with TV series such as The Big Bang Theory, the Marvel Cinematic Universe and popular music artists like Beyoncé. Globalization however, is not the same as Americanization: Indian movies, South Korean popular culture (K-wave) and formats such as The Voice are sold and consumed all over the world. In this course the meanings of developments in the media industries for production, content and consumption of media products is scrutinized. Due to their global presence entertainment genres form the focal point of this course. To critically examine cultural globalization in relation to media industries and the symbolic meanings produced the ‘critical political economy’ approach is adopted.

column1: During this course students will explore the multidimensional nature of the legal orders (a new development) that lawyers are confronted with in a globalized world. The focus will be on how various international and European Union legal orders, but also transnational legal orders (think e.g. of the Forest Stewardship Council wood certification scheme), inter-relate and how they relate to the values enshrined in national legal orders. The point of departure for the course will be how the internationalization and Europeanization of law relate to enhanced economic integration and interdependence (i.e. globalization) and may compromise values that are regarded as essential to law as developed in liberal legal orders. These essential values include those related to the rule of law, human rights and democracy. In other words, during the course, legal developments related to enhanced economic interdependence, often resulting in technocratic decision-making at international and European levels of decision making, will be problematized in an interdisciplinary context.

The course builds on the knowledge, insights and skills acquired during the course Research and Writing Skills (Block 1) in European Union, International Law and Global Governance (Block 2) and The Law and Policy of European Integration (Block 2) and in particular seeks to broaden the student’s knowledge of the processes already introduced in the previous courses and enhance his/her legal and research skills, both in writing and oral format.

The course is problem-based, in the sense that real-world issues/themes are the point of departure; it thus takes an inductive approach. That said, in considering these issues students will be prompted to master systemic critical analysis, integrating concepts which are essential components of the systems of international and European Union law.
The theme for this year are:

column2: • Sustainability in the international regime on trade and investment
• The environment and the climate change regime
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Students completing this course will  be able to independently:

column2: • Describe, analyse and critically assess new developments in international and European Union law and the causes thereof;
• Describe, analyze and critically assess the consequences of a multidimensional legal order, integrating the findings of other disciplines, in particular political science, sociology and economics;

• Engage in legal comparison and integration, that is comparing and integrating legal developments at an international and EU level in relation to each other and to legal values associated with national legal orders; and as a consequence:
• Conduct systemic, horizontal and vertical legal analysis;
• Develop, conduct and account for academic research  on issues pertaining to globalisation and multidimensional legal orders.
• Develop and present different types of legal advice on pertinent legal problems (taking into account ethical considerations), both orally and writing.

column1: The so-called Islamic State recruits members from around the world for their cause through Twitter. Netflix recently declared that after analysing their browsing statistics, they realized that the old constructs of cultural taste in association with the usual suspects of gender, class and age are irrelevant in their algorithmic design. Solidarity marches are happening more frequently around the world –the Occupy movement, Women’s march, and March for Science. What these diverse phenomena are pointing out today is that we live in an increasingly global world where through social media, we are able to create new forms of communities, cultures and contexts that go beyond national borders.

Hence, it is worth asking: Is the notion of the nation state redundant? Does culture matter today in the age of the internet? As social networking sites and their impact spans across borders, are we living in a post-cultural age? To talk of global and representative practice, we need to expand our frames of reference, revisit sacred discourses and Western-biased rubrics of digital design and practice. A paradigm shift is needed in approaching cultural phenomena on the internet with a more global-oriented, open- ended and pluralistic perspective. This seminar investigates popular events, claims and trends by going into the history of dominant theories of influence over these decades including (post) structuralism, (post) modernism, (post) Marxism, feminism and (post)colonial discourse .This opens up critical discussions on key topics such as privacy/surveillance, labour/leisure, activism, democracy, and media consumption/production.  This is essential for students to be able to position their research and target audience within a more globally architected digital and cultural landscape.

column1: The course is open to all Research Master students, PhD candidates and faculty members. It is assumed that participants have some basic knowledge on how to interpret analyses. For teaching and practice purposes, participants will use simulated datasets.

Discuss what meta-analysis is and how it has been applied in management and economics over the years. We will focus on the three general goals (determine overall size of an effect, moderator analyses, mediation analyses) and discuss steps 1 and 2 above.
Discuss extensively steps 3 and 4 and do some short exercises on how to develop a questionnaire and start coding of studies.

Discuss step 5 and do analyses together in a computer lab. If there is time, Marc will also focus on some of his new work and new possibilities in meta-analyses. In the afternoon there is time for some individual appointments.

We expect this to be an interactive class. We expect that everyone is an active and motivated participant, is prepared to ask questions, discuss alternative views, and contribute to the flow of the class. For further information please contact Marc van Essen (marc.vanessen@moore.sc.edu)

Marc van Essen (Ph.D. Erasmus University) is an Professor of International Business at the Moore School of Business, University of South Carolina and permanent visiting professor at EM Lyon Business School, France. His research interests include international business, non-market strategy, corporate governance, family firm strategy, and meta-analytic research methods. His works applying meta-analysis have been published or are forthcoming in the following journals: Academy of Management Journal, Journal of Banking and Finance, Journal of International Business Studies, Journal of Management, Journal of Management Studies, and Organization Science, and other outlets.

Marc brings understanding of leading-edge meta-analytical approaches in management and economics. This is a great opportunity to receive training and obtain knowledge on a very current data analysis technique from one of the most accredited scholars using it.</body>

column4: This module introduces the students to ‘law and governance’ by focusing on a field that combines both perspectives: regulatory governance. ‘Regulation’, which is not necessarily a synonym for ‘rulemaking’, is central to governing society. The regulatory approach to law and governance recognizes that law cannot solve all societal problems but also that law brings important safeguards to the table. The governance perspective points to the importance of solid institutional design and culture. Why do we regulate and what do we know about different regulatory approaches, including self-regulation? In what ways do international organisations and NGOs try to influence domestic regulatory governance? The course also deals with the possibilities and limitations of regulatory impact analysis and participation as central governance tools.

The module takes a practical approach, using group work on case studies as a way of gaining experience with the application of tools and concepts of regulatory governance in the context of public administration and law making.

column1: Healthcare managers increasingly are confronted with changes in the policy environment affecting the ways they organize and manage daily care processes. For example, legal requirements for patient participation force healthcare managers to install patient representatives in their advisory boards, and safety regulations ask for structured ways of organizing and accounting for the quality of care within healthcare organizations. Policy measures also influence the strategic choices of managers; if patient safety is displayed as an important problem in healthcare, rendering patient safety a top priority of the healthcare institution can be a valuable way of presenting the institution to third-party payers and patients.

Yet, incorporating national policy aims and measures in the organization’s policies also transforms the role of the healthcare organization. A healthcare organization is not a neutral adaptor of national policy requirements, but actively gives shape to these policies. For instance, what patient participation means and how the actual role of patients in the healthcare organization’s decision making process is fleshed out in practice, gets shape in the day-to-day interactions between health care managers, healthcare practitioners and quality staff.
This course aims to provide HCM students with theoretical lenses as well as practical knowledge to the understanding and dealing with governance and strategy issues in healthcare organizations.
Language: Only the workgroups are in Dutch

Healthcare managers increasingly are confronted with changes in the policy environment affecting the ways they organize and manage daily care processes. For example, legal requirements for patient participation force healthcare managers to install patient representatives in their advisory boards, and safety regulations ask for structured ways of organizing and accounting for the quality of care within healthcare organizations. Policy measures also influence the strategic choices of managers; if patient safety is displayed as an important problem in healthcare, rendering patient safety a top priority of the healthcare institution can be a valuable way of presenting the institution to third-party payers and patients.

Yet, incorporating national policy aims and measures in the organization’s policies also transforms the role of the healthcare organization. A healthcare organization is not a neutral adaptor of national policy requirements, but actively gives shape to these policies. For instance, what patient participation means and how the actual role of patients in the healthcare organization’s decision making process is fleshed out in practice, gets shape in the day-to-day interactions between health care managers, healthcare practitioners and quality staff.
This course aims to provide HCM students with theoretical lenses as well as practical knowledge to the understanding and dealing with governance and strategy issues in healthcare organizations.

column1: This course is coordinated by the Erasmus University Rotterdam and given jointly with University of Leiden, and Institute of Social Science, and is part of the Governance of Migration and Diversity Master programme.

This course offers a multidisciplinary outlook on governance of migration and diversity from the perspectives of public administration, history, sociology and development studies.  The course aims to stimulate a dialogue between the practice of migration and diversity governance and a variety of theoretical perspectives on governance. During the seminars and site-visits the students are given the opportunity to engage in discussions with both scholars and practitioners of governance.

The course consists of seminars and field trips (or webinars). It includes two introductory lectures about the structure of the course and about the foundations of  governance theory. The following eight sessions will be conducted by governance scholars working within disciplinary traditions of Public Administration, Sociology, History and Development Studies, each seminar introducing the topic and new aspects of governance theory will be followed up by a site visit  to the organizations, where students are expected to engage in conversation with practitioners of governance.
NB. Due to COVID-19 situation in the country, the visits to the sites may be replaced by webinars with practitioners from the organizations.</body>

• Relate these theories and perspectives to real-life cases of governance of migration and diversity;

• Write a policy brief and develop recommendations for various governance actors to improve their governance practice (grounded in real-life cases, based on scientific evidence and theoretical perspectives).

column1: Cities are increasingly seen as important places to ‘govern’ health. In the Netherlands, cities have gained more responsibilities since the decentralizations of care and support to local municipalities. On the local level, solutions need to be found for pressing problems, such as rising health inequalities between neighbourhoods, fragmented public service provision, and unsuitable housing for aging populations. To address these problems in innovative ways, experiments are being conducted in urban labs and inter-sectoral networks are set-up to enhance collaboration between different stakeholders in the city.

In this course we explore the ways in which urban health has come to be governed in modern societies. Governance, in the literature as well as in practices, stands for policy without central policy actors. That is: policymaking and implementation have come to rest on a myriad of actors and perspectives that are interwoven in networks. The course therefore serves as a guide to how urban governance for health is being done. This will be discussed both on a theoretical level (using concepts) and on practical level (using urban action research).

During the course students will work together with a field partner in Rotterdam on a specific urban issue. This ‘action-research’ will allow students to delve deeper into an urban problem and propose policy recommendations for solving it. Grading is based on a group paper, where theoretical concepts and recommendations for practice come together, and on an individual open-questions exam.</body>

column2: • Students have an understanding of the shift from government to governance
• Students have an understanding of different coordination modes in governance (market, state, networks and communities)
• Students can explain the connection between place and healthcare governance.
• Students can apply theoretical concepts from the literature to analyze empirical cases of healthcare governance (see the 2 cases in Feijenoord, Rotterdam)
• Students will be able to develop useful policy recommendations for Feijenoord on the basis of the key concepts and themes of this course
• Students are able to explain and critically reflect on how people can be ‘responsibilized’ and be ‘made governable’
• Students are able to effectively discuss literature and issues on governance during meetings
• Students are able to provide peer-support to each other during workgroups by reading and discussing each other’s draft version of the report
• Students are able to write a coherent essay on the basis of a clear research question.

column1: When it comes to social inequalities, policies and institutional arrangements are part of the equation. They help shaping the incidence and consequences of our endowments and of the events we experience during our life – and often do so unequally. Policies and institutions may in fact mitigate social disparities, build some anew, magnify others, or even do all of the above at once. The result is often composite, a patchwork of trade-offs and unintended consequences cutting across the social fabric.

In this course we will examine a number of policies and institutional arrangements implicated in the (re)production of social inequalities. We will explore theory- and evidence- based accounts of these policies and institutions, of their features and effects as examined across the social sciences. Emphasis will be given to current debates, both academic and public, and to the organisation of informed debates within the class. Particular attention will be devoted, but by all means will not be limited, to the realms of welfare provision and labour markets. Most of all, the course will focus on four axes of social inequality, namely gender, generation and cohort, race and ethnicity, and class.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>After successful completion of this course, students will be able to:

column2: • Review and analyse theory- and evidence-based accounts of the features and consequences of different policies and institutions, with a particular emphasis on the (re)production of social inequalities;
• Reflect on how policies and institutions respond to socio-economic, demographic, and political developments;

• Identify trade-offs and unintended consequences of policies and institutional arrangements, i.e. how policies and institutions might mitigate some social inequalities while simultaneously producing or intensifying others;
• Apply a theoretical “toolbox”, built on the insights of sociology and (equally) of other social sciences, to analyse policies/institutions and their consequences.

column1: After successful completion of this course, students will be able to:

column2: • Make informed policy recommendations, especially in the realm of social policies or other institutions implicated in social inequalities;
• Report and summarise findings in a clear and effective manner (in writing).

column1: Cities are dynamic engines of economies growth and innovation, but they also create negative externalities such as inequality, poverty and pollution. Urban economies are primarily coordinated by market transactions, many of which take place at an (inter)national level. The ability of urban governments to influence markets is limited and widely discussed. The course adopts a network governance perspective, debating if and how varying combinations of markets, state and non-state actors steer and facilitate local economic development. The question is if and how urban network governance can stimulate economic growth and innovation, while overcoming negative externalities.

The course first discusses multi-disciplinary factors driving economic growth, creativity, innovation and entrepreneurship in a global economy. Subsequently the section zooms in on transitions towards sustainable and resilient urban economies, responding to recent challenges such as climate change, financial crises, growing inequality and the Brexit.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column2: • Distinguish and apply different perspectives to urban economic governance
• Analyze the complex nature of urban economic governance across and within sectors and cities
• Formulate conditions for sustainable and inclusive urban economic growth and inclusive innovation
• Determinate strategies to overcome negative externalities (like poverty, inequality and pollution)

It is no coincidence that our psychology curriculum in Rotterdam begins with a course about people in groups (social psychology). Groups were central to the human past, are central to our present, and will continue to be central to the human future. To understand human behavior, we need to understand groups, because people live in groups, play in groups, and.... work and perform in groups.

As a Work and Organizational Psychologist, you will be faced with groups at work all the time: departments, project teams, discussion groups, boards, work teams, et cetera. Often, your involvement with groups will be about improving them, about suggesting or implementing changes to make groups or teams more effective. In your future job you may, for example, train groups, build groups (or teams), advise groups, design groups, disband groups, address groups, motivate groups, study groups, or simply participate in groups.

By presenting state-of-the-art knowledge about various aspects of groups at work, this course will give you the opportunity to prepare for these and other intriguing encounters with the practice of group work.

column1: Human Resources have increasingly been recognised as a source of competitive advantage and as such good people management is vital for organisations. The course is designed to develop a thorough knowledge and understanding of the effective management of people. After exploring the theoretical origins of HRM, the emergence of HR strategy and the relationship between business strategy and HRM strategy, the course will focus on discussing and analysing important HRM activities such as HR planning, job analysis and job design, recruitment and selection, and performance management.   A deepened understanding of the strategic character of these practical HRM activities provides students with the knowledge and skills required for the integration of HR policies into a coherent HRM strategy, which implementation will contribute to a high-performance organisation.

column1: In this course we will focus on examining the impact of three key global mega trends on HR theory and practice: increasing digitisation of the workplace, changing workforce demographics, and new ways of organizing in knowledge-intensive industries. Each week you will focus on one key mega trend and your learning will be through short introductory lectures, in-class activities (including presentations, case analyses, and debates), and online discussions through Canvas. This course is highly interactive, and your preparation for the online and in-class activities is based on completing the assigned readings prior to each class. Students who have completed this course are able to analyse and act upon key global mega trends that affect the management of people in working organizations.

In Week 1, we will be looking at the effects of digitization on human resource management. Questions that will be explored include (a) the relationship between digitization and phenomena such as Big data, data science, and people-/HR-analytics, (b) the bright side and the dark side of digitization, and (c) the potential of digitization versus the present reality. The last of these you will be exploring yourselves as well, by engaging in a short study of the current use of HR Tech.

In Week 2, we will focus on demographic change and the implications for the management of employees’ work experience. We will engage in some “myths busting” around aging, generations, and age diversity at work. You will select a challenge related to management of aging and agediverse workforces, and (a) analyse the challenge using data, (b) present a company example facing the challenge, and (c) design an evidence-based HR practice addressing the challenge.

In Week 3, we will examine the new ways of organizing adopted by professionals in knowledge-intensive industries, with a focus on freelancers in the IT and creative sector. We will analyze the advantages and challenges of atomized freelancing, collectively organized freelancing, and traditional employment. column1: This course offers students the opportunity to conduct an internship on a topic of their own interest. An internship can help students to apply their theoretical knowledge as well as develop their professional attitude including skills such as organizing, planning, analyzing data and professionals collaboration with coworkers.

This course offers internships via two possible tracks; a practice-based and a research-based track. Students are themselves responsible for finding a practice-based internship, while we can place students interested in a research-based internship on an ongoing project of faculty. This can include a project that is offered by staff working on issues in human resources management, organizational change, organization theory and/or organizational behavior.

The duration of the internship is at least equivalent to 5-6 weeks full-time work, but can also be spread over a longer period of time or be conducted on a part-time basis. The research-based internship will most likely be part-time and the timeframe is determined in consultation with the staff. The planning of the practice-based internship depends on the organization involved.
Course starts in Block 3 with one plenary session and ends in Block 5 with a final presentation session.

column1: Macro principles of good writing and publishing (Day 1)
1.    What makes a paper a good paper; why do some paper get published and others not
3.    Writing as a contribution to scholarly discourse: Finding your conversation, finding a story to tell
4.    Structuring a paper: Different options and when they are appropriate.
6.    Knowing the key ingredients for each section of a paper: what has go into an introduction, a literature review, etc., and where exactly should it be located.
7.    Good sections, good paragraphing (pyramid principle, topic sentences etc.)
8.    Rules for building strong sentences, cohesion among sentences (e.g., relating to action characters, strong verbs, 2-3-1, pargraphing, creating overlap, from known to unknown, concision)
9.    Choice of tense and mode to fit section of the paper and the content, choice of words that send the right “signals”, etc.
10.    Conducting your writing project: Strategies for productive writing and editing
11.    Writing to get published in leading academic journals
14.    Measuring and managing your impact as a scholar
Prerequisites: First writing experience (in English). Please note that attendance is expected on all three days.</body>

column1: This course aims at improving participants’ academic writing skills, and help them to publish papers at leading journals. The course is an intensive one-week course, where participants are expected to focus exclusively on this course. Participants are expected to submit a piece of writing before the start of the seminar. This can be a draft of a conference paper or a draft of a regular paper. During the course, you will be invited to revise the written piece after each day. At the end of the course, the initially submitted piece of writing should be revised substantially and should be re-submitted to the professor. Participants should also actively take part in the discussions

column2: • At the end of this course, participants know how to craft high quality papers.
• Participants know the principles of good academic writing, and recognize these principles.
• Participants improve their own writing and editing.
• Participants understand the publishing process, including research ethics issues that can arise in its course.
• Participants understand how scholarly impact is created and measured, and can apply this knowledge to increase their own impact.
• Participants get an understanding why many papers get rejected.

column1: <body>De economie draait op het kopen en verkopen van de meest diverse goederen en diensten. Allereerst wordt daarom aandacht besteed aan het (internationale) kooprecht. Wat zijn de rechten en verplichtingen van koper en verkoper? In handelstransacties zijn koper en verkoper meestal niet op dezelfde plaats gevestigd. De verkochte goederen zullen dus vervoerd moeten worden. Wat indien de goederen tijdens dit transport beschadigd worden? Het vervoerrecht regelt de rechten en verplichtingen van de partijen die bij het vervoer betrokken zijn. De gekochte goederen moeten uiteraard ook betaald worden. Wanneer koper en verkoper zich niet op dezelfde plaats bevinden wordt het uitvoeren van een betaling minder evident, zeker wanneer koper en verkoper elkaar niet per se vertrouwen. De handelspraktijk heeft hiervoor verschillende oplossingen uitgewerkt, die in belangrijke mate berusten op het concept van waardepapieren. In het onderdeel betalingstechnieken en waardepapieren wordt hieraan aandacht besteed. Wanneer in een transactie iets mis loopt, is het zeer wel denkbaar dat de schadelijder een aansprakelijksvordering heeft op een andere partij. Het instellen van een vorderingen kosten echter tijd en geld, en draagt steeds een procesrisico in zich. Vaak zullen de partijen bij een handelstransactie risico's dan ook verzekeren, zodat zij zich bij een schadegeval tot hun verzekeraar kunnen wenden i.p.v. de uitkomst van een procedure te moeten afwachten. Het verzekeringsrecht regelt de rechten en plichten van partijen in het kader van een verzekeringsovereenkomst. Tenslotte wordt aandacht besteed aan twee rechtsdomeinen die niet noodzakelijk, maar wel vaak een rol spelen bij handelstransacties. Vooreerst het recht inzake handelstussenpersonen. Producenten willen hun producten vaak ook wel in het buitenland aanbieden, maar vinden het moeilijk om dit vanop afstand te doen, en maken daarom gebruik van plaatselijke tussenpersonen (distributeurs, handelsagenten, enz.). De opdrachtgever en de tussenpersoon hebben soms echter uiteenlopende of zelfs tegenstrijdige belangen, wat in de praktijk regelmatig tot problemen aanleiding geeft. Het handelstussenpersonenrecht regelt deze materie. Tenslotte wordt aandacht besteed aan het intellectuele eigendomsrecht. Producenten investeren tijd en geld in de ontwikkeling van producten, en worden door het intellectuele eigendomsrecht beschermd tegen ongeoorloofd kopiëren en namaak.</body>

column1: The Syrian civil war, the Ebola epidemic, Covid-19, hurricane Katrina, the Rohingya crisis, the earthquakes in Nepal and Haiti, the Japanese tsunami, the Indian Ocean tsunami, the HIV/AIDS epidemic,… the world has experienced many large humanitarian crises in past decades. Climate change, population growth, and rapid urbanization will likely only increase their frequency and impact in the future. At the same time, the world is still facing several substantial development challenges. For example, nearly 2 billion people still lack access to basic medicines and more than half the world population still lacks access to essential health services.

These health and humanitarian crises come with extreme demands for logistics, technology, and operations management. Extreme in terms of operating conditions. Extreme due to the scarcity of resources. And extreme in terms of consequences for health and well-being. For example, managing disaster response is like organizing the next Olympic Games without knowing where it will take place, when it will take place, and how many people will come. Though this seems pretty impossible, the way response is being prepared and managed is a matter of life and death for many. Similarly, increasing access to medicines and health services in low and middle income countries is about addressing a disproportionally heavy burden of disease with very limited resources (doctors, clinics, outreach/vaccination teams, transportation, infrastructures, money…). Maximizing the effectiveness of available resources is hence key, which is exactly what logistics, technology, and operations management is about.

This course provides an introduction to the important field of Health & Humanitarian Logistics and corresponding UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). Though it covers some theory, the main focus will be on learning by doing. Through case studies, a simulation game, guest lectures from people who work in the humanitarian sector, individual and group exercises, you will work on real and complex challenges related to disaster relief, medicine supply chains, and health service delivery in low and middle income countries. Examples include: Where should one locate warehouses to pre-position relief goods? What/how much to stock there? What logistics network should one set up to handle incoming relief goods after a disaster? How to optimize the dispatching of these goods? What technology is useful to support relief activities? Should governments adopt a push or a pull system for medicine supplies to health facilities? Are vendor-managed inventories a solution for weak inventory management skills in pharmacies and clinics? Should drones be used to perform medicine deliveries? In what contexts should one use mobile (i.e., travelling) healthcare providers instead of traditional health facilities? How to screen for epidemic outbreaks?

Given the increasing need for smart use of data in this sector, much emphasis will be put on analyzing datasets and using analytics techniques to support decisions/ generate insights. While doing so, you will be asked to use the knowledge, methods, and models you have acquainted yourself with during your studies. If you have a background in logistics and supply chain management, you are encouraged to use data analysis and optimization techniques and mathematical models (e.g., for network design, planning, routing, and inventory control). If you are not familiar with these methods and models, you are encouraged to address the challenge using your intuition and methods and models you are familiar with. All students will be challenged to critically assess applicability of such methods and models (which have typically been developed to address business challenges) to the challenge considered. What are the hidden assumptions? What pieces can be transferred? What pieces need to be adjusted?
In parallel, the course will cover some basic concepts, background knowledge, and theory about Health & Humanitarian Logistics, including:
-    The goals the health & humanitarian system aims to achieve,
-    The stakeholders in the health and humanitarian system,
-    How the system works (or is supposed to work),
-    The context in which health and humanitarian actors operate,
-    Objectives and their quantification (e.g., through disease state modelling and epidemic modelling)
-    The role of logistics in the system, and key logistics challenges,
-    New technology (e.g., blockchain, drones) and new business models for addressing these challenges,
-    Technology and management approaches for logistics decision making

Though the course will have a major focus on logistics and supply chain management, students from all MSc programs are encouraged to participate, and haven’t faced difficulties in doing so. Many challenges in the health & humanitarian system are multi-faceted, and relate to/ benefit from knowledge from various disciplines, including analytics, strategy, finance, innovation, etc. </body>

column1: The main objective of this course is to introduce you to big open problems in the health and humanitarian sector, to critically assess transferability of business school knowledge, models, and methods and to creatively adjust or add to them. Upon completing this course, students can:
-    Explain the general goals the health & humanitarian system aims to achieve, the role of different stakeholders in this system, and the big challenges it is facing,
-    Identify the role of logistics in addressing these challenges,
-    Generate solutions for/ insights on several of these challenges, often in a data-driven manner,
-    Assess applicability of related models (e.g., facility location, inventory control, planning, and routing) while addressing these challenges,
-    Adjust such models to account for the specifics of the challenge and context considered,
-    Discuss the potential of new technologies and business models to address challenges the health & humanitarian system is facing</body>

column1: <body>This course will introduce students to economic analysis of health and health care. The health care sector is a more and more important sector of the economy, with health care expenditures having reached 10% of GDP in most OECD countries. The performance of health care systems still has a lot to benefit from sound economic analysis. We will start by addressing the question of what makes health care a different economic good. The special features of health care mean that the standard economic tools are not sufficient to study its demand and supply. We will learn the main economic models that have been developed to analyse these issues. This course will also provide an introduction to economic evaluation of health care. This area of health economics provides information on which products - health care interventions - should be provided for consumption by patients, by weighing the costs and benefits of various alternatives. In many instances, such information is now required for new technologies to get access to the health care market. Questions that will be addressed include:

column2: • Do doctors induce unnecessary demand for their services?
• Can poor people pay for their own health insurance?
• Should health insurance premia depend on how (un)healthy people are?
• Do poor people in developed and developing countries have access to the health care services they need?
• How to determine the value/utility that people attach to health?
• What health care services should be included in the basic insurance package?

column1: Instructors: Prof. O.A. O’Donnell (EUR) and Prof. M. Lindeboom (VU)

Health is an important dimension of wellbeing. Its value is evident from our willingness in high-income countries to spend around 9 percent of GDP on healthcare. And in the US, almost twice this fraction of income is spent on healthcare. Health economics examines whether the level of health spending is efficient and its distribution is fair. It is also concerned with how to finance this spending to strike the right balance between efficiency and equity. Less obviously perhaps, economics can be used to explain variation in health itself by viewing health behaviour as resulting from constrained optimisation of either a fully rational agent or one that is prone to psychological biases. In addition to explaining health behaviour, economics examines the influence of health on economic behaviour and outcomes. Current circumstances make it all too evident that economic activity is highly contingent on population health.

This course covers some of these health-related applications of economics. The first session examines health inequality. We evaluate the success of economic theory and empirical methods in explaining differences in health by education, wealth and income. The second session considers effects of health on economic behaviour and outcomes. While the research discussed in the first two sessions seeks to explain phenomena, the third session turns to research with a prescriptive purpose: the design of policies to control communicable diseases and prevent non-communicable ones. The fourth session switches attention from health to the financing of healthcare; specifically, the efficiency of health insurance, and its potential contribution to the much higher spending on healthcare in the US.

The fifth session examines the hypothesis that health and economic outcomes in adult life and old age are the result of long run mechanisms that originate very early in life. The penultimate session examines socioeconomic determinants of a major cause of ill-health – smoking – while the last session considers the impact of work and retirement on health.

6. present a concise, clear written argument related to a health phenomenon or policy founded on economic analysis with reference to relevant evidence from health economics research.
