column1: In this course students will learn how they can use psychological theories to design and evaluate effective interventions. Together with our experts, they will take on the challenge to analyse, investigate and solve complex behavioral problems. They will start with exploring how psychological processes are linked to behaviors, and how they can use these insights to design interventions that change targeted behaviors and promote healthier choices.

The course will explore how psychological, behavioral and sociocultural factors influence health. The course will investigate how some of the most relevant societal challenges and health problems (e.g. behaviors related to infectious diseases, obesity, cancer) can be tackled through behavior change interventions. The course will give students the opportunity to apply the Behavior Change Wheel (BCW) for developing effective behavioral change interventions. This implies that, besides learning about behavior change theories, students will get hands-on experience with the steps involved in developing behavior change interventions to tackle current health problems.

column2: • Students will learn about theories on health psychology and behavior change and their applications in daily practice in weekly lectures. A series of show-cases from practice will be presented on a variety of topics, such as promoting healthy eating in school canteens, physical activity at work, prevention of sexual harassment and management of addictive behaviors.

• During the workshops, students will practice techniques of designing interventions. The steps of the BCW will be central. Experts will present examples of interventions and the ins and outs of design and implementation. The examples will focus on healthy eating in the first half of the workshops and on physical activity in the second half.
• The workshops will be rich on assignments taken from practice on which student work together using interactive learning activities.

column1: Upon completion of the course students should have provided evidence of being able to demonstrate a sophisticated, in-depth, and critical understanding of theory, assessment and intervention regarding psychological approaches to health. They are also able to critically and creatively evaluate current issues, research and advanced scholarship in the area of psychological approaches to health.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: At the end of this course you will be able to...

column2: • Outline the magnitude of a public health problem with available evidence from recognized resources.
• Identify from the available evidence what health risk factors, behavioral determinants, and sociocultural factors influence public health problems.
• Distinguish theories and models of health behavior
• Estimate behavior change theories and techniques in public health by addressing their strengths and limitations.
• Argue the challenges of behavior change interventions and policies to intervene in the public health problems in today's society.
• Apply the Behavior Change Wheel framework for developing effective behavior change interventions (BCIs) to tackle current health problems.
• Systematically design a behavior change intervention based on theory and empirical evidence, and professionally and convincingly present the intervention proposal, both oral and in writing.
• Critically judge scientific publications in the field of behavior change and its effect studies, accounting for methodological rigor, theoretical soundness, and relevance.
• Distinguish stakeholders in the field of public health and analyze their aims and counterarguments concerning behavior change interventions.

column1: Why do people smoke, refuse vaccination, have unsafe sex, eat unhealthily and are physically inactive despite the health risks? How can we help individuals, communities and societies to live healthier and maintain these behaviours to prevent illness? In this course, we will explain how health psychology can be used to address behaviours that can affect our health. We will do this by

(1) explaining how biological, psychological, and sociocultural factors contribute to physical, mental, and social wellbeing, and by (2) exploring health promotion intervention design in a hands- on manner, using the intervention mapping approach. This course is about theory, evidence, practical applications and a glimpse into the real-world.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>Upon completion of this course, you should be able to:

column2: • Understand the reasons underlying the emergence of health psychology;
• Have a basic understanding of the public health consequences of hypertension, diabetes, and sexually transmitted diseases;
• Understand the determinants of health behaviour and identify effective methods of promoting behaviour change and healthier lifestyles;
• Understand the main health risks and positive health behaviours that are relevant to the population at large;
• Understand the role of health behaviours for determining health outcomes;
• Become familiar with behaviour change theories in public health;
• Identify trends in research about the evidence based clinical behaviour of health care professionals;
• Discuss the role of theories and techniques of behaviour change;
• Learn from the experiences of a GP working in the South of Rotterdam;
• Understand sociocultural differences of health and illness;
• Become familiar with a theoretical framework to understand cultural differences and similarities;
• Apply behaviour change theories to design a pilot intervention focused on hypertension/diabetes/sexual and reproductive health;
• Appreciate the challenges and opportunities associated with running an intervention in the field.

column1: We will focus on the development of health service operations management as a field of research, its relevance to develop and improve health services and on the basic concepts of health service operations management. We will use Operations Management theory and concepts for the operations management of individual units within health service provider organizations (e.g. a ward) and for the operations management of care pathways (e.g. mamma cancer diagnosis and treatment) and care chains (e.g. stroke services).

Furthermore we will discuss the concepts underlying Focused Factory, Lean Management, Six Sigma, Business Process Redesign and Theory of Constraints as these are popular approaches in operations management used in continuous improvement of processes in health services. All topics will be introduced in lectures and put into practice in workgroups. Quantitative analyses (with Excel) will be part of both the working group assignments and the individual assignment. To prepare, test and update your Excel knowledge, a formative test in excel is available on the website (Excel skills).
Language: Only the workgroups are in Dutch</body>

Health Service Operations Management (HSOM) can be defined as the analysis, design, planning and control of all steps necessary to deliver services to clients in healthcare. We use methods and techniques that originate from manufacturing but have been adapted to service industries and health services.

The aim of the course is to make the students familiar with the basic concepts, methods and techniques of health service operations management and to enable them to apply these concepts to services in healthcare.

column1: The course focuses on the question; How can organizations develop and evaluate innovative services in health care. The course provides an introduction to innovation science.  Innovations science is interdisciplinary; it combines knowledge from the field of economics, sociology, change management and organizational sciences. Specific questions we will address in this course are: What is the value of specific innovations? What impact do technologies have on clinical practice? Why do certain innovations emerge while others do not? How can you evaluate an innovation (is it better compared to what, who, whom)?

In this course students are asked to participate in an innovation contest (comparable to the Dutch Health Care innovation Award). The examination of the course represents all elements of innovation and implementation processes. Students are asked to write a proposal, to present this proposal to both health care professionals, managers and board members and to review an innovation proposal

column1: Although patients demand access to all health care programmes available, the scarcity of resources necessitates that choices have to be made. Given that health is such an important matter and that choices usually have far reaching consequences for individuals, the choices require careful consideration, preferably based on transparent and unbiased data. Health Technology Assessment is a multidisciplinary research area closely related to health economics. HTA research attempts to examine the short- and long-term consequences (e.g. health effects and costs) of new and existing health care programs. This is done in a systematic and consistent way in order to provide evidence for the relative cost-effectiveness of health care programs. Policy makers in health care are increasingly using the results of these studies in making choices on priorities in health care.

column1: In this course you will learn how to perform and critically review a HTA.
By the end of the course students can:
- describe the structure and the objectives of HTA/economic evaluation studies.
- perform the 6 steps of an economic evaluation study.
- describe and discuss the inclusion, measurement and valuation of future costs, productivity costs, informal care and outcomes beyond the QALY in economic evaluations
- explain advantages and disadvantages of various quality of life instruments and can discuss when and how individual instruments should be used.
- explain the relationship between several economic theories and the differences in operationalization of key concepts in economic evaluation studies.
- perform and interpret cost- and cost-effectiveness calculations including analysis of uncertainty with a decision tree and a Markov disease model and reflect upon the design and quality of studies.
- critically discuss the inclusion of economic evaluations  among other policy ingredients in policy reimbursement decisions of new health care interventions.
- explain the difficulties of transferring outcomes of economic evaluations across jurisdictions.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Conflicts and dilemmas in healthcare are rarely merely technical problems. They tend to have profound moral dimensions which are often overlooked. Policy-advisors as well as managers need to be sensitive to the moral aspects of conflicts and dilemmas occurring in healthcare. Sensibility for the moral side of problems (in healthcare as well as anywhere else) is not self-evident. It is something which must be acquired. In addition, moral problems are also problems which can be solved. Moral reasoning is something that can be learned.

The course introduces students to moral philosophy. What is morality? What constitutes a moral dilemma? Why be moral? Is there truth in morality? What qualifies an act morally? What constitutes moral character? Following these meta-ethical questions, the course surveys major normative ethical theories (including utilitarianism, rights theory and virtue theory), describes methods of moral justification in healthcare ethics, addresses the problem of moral status and agency (what rights people are due, and when) and examines the moral characteristics of the basic relationships (e.g. professionals-patients and clients) inherent to healthcare.

Drawing from contemporary research, case studies and real-life examples, students will learn how the fundamental moral principles of autonomy, benevolence and justice can be expanded to apply to various conflicts and dilemmas in healthcare, from whether or not to withhold or withdraw life-sustaining treatments, to such diverse issues as the legislation of organ donation (opt-in or opt-out?), euthanasia and fulfilled lives, life style choices, access to collectively financed healthcare and solidarity, and expensive drugs and the worth of human life.

At the end of the course, students will have learned that the reasoning typical of the disciplines constituting health sciences, such as (health) economics and (health) law, are but different ways to approach normative problems in healthcare, that there is a common (ethical) language, and that there is a way to include them all when faced with such problems.

In interactive lectures students will be made familiar with the basics of philosophical ethics, healthcare ethics and moral reasoning. In the seminars the theory will be put to practice. During the course students will apply the same method of moral reasoning to a variety of moral problems in healthcare in ever smaller groups. Finally, the individual student is expected to write an essay, providing a moral question of his or her choice, but approved by the staff, by the best possible answer, in the way taught in the seminars.

• The student acquires knowledge and an understanding of the basics of health care ethics
• The student acquires basic moral reasoning skills
• The student is able to apply basic moral reasoning skills to real-life moral dilemmas in healthcare
• The student engages actively in moral discussions
• The student is able to hold a moral position convincingly, expressed in a well-written essay, based on well-researched arguments and sound logic

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In this course we will focus on the procurement process and on value chain management in the healthcare sector. In many countries, healthcare represents one of the largest sectors of the economy; healthcare spend often amounts to 10% of a country’s GDP. This course builds on the key concepts as taught in the core course Purchasing & Supply Management (BM05SCM). This course expands into areas that are not only relevant in healthcare, but also in other sectors, such as services triads, performance-based contracting, best value procurement, European tendering, cooperative purchasing, and negotiation skills.

In healthcare value chains two types of purchasing can be distinguished: purchasing of healthcare and purchasing for healthcare. In purchasing of healthcare, which is done by for instance healthcare insurers, ‘healthcare’ is the service that is purchased. In purchasing for healthcare a diverse set of goods and services is purchased (e.g. catering, temporary labour and medical equipment).

A significant amount of money is spent in the healthcare industry on a yearly basis, which makes that there is a large potential for the purchasing profession to decrease spend, improve quality and increase innovation as well as efficiency. In this course we connect management theory about purchasing with specific characteristics of the healthcare industry.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course brings together students from the institute of Healthcare Policy and Management and Rotterdam School of Management to educate them on procurement in the healthcare sector. The course is a mix of lectures and workshops, some of which will be taught by experienced guest lecturers from organizations such as hospitals and insurance companies. The workshops are sessions with 10-20 students, in which there will be ample opportunity to discuss the concepts in-depth and/or to practice specific skills.
For the schedule please refer to the GW4009MD and GW4009MV schedules.

Students will get to understand the role that purchasing plays within and between healthcare organisations and the different ways in which purchasing can contribute to the overall performance of a healthcare organisation and/or a healthcare system. Upon completing this course, students:

column2: •     Can explain the importance of professional purchasing and supply management in healthcare systems;
•     Understand the role that incentives play in buyer-supplier relationships;
•     Understand the importance of supplier relationship management and know the advantages and disadvantages of different types of supplier relationships;
•     Understand the importance of alignment between purchasing and medical professionals and how to achieve such alignment;
•     Can describe the advantages of horizontal buyer-supplier collaboration and the different types of buyer-supplier relationships;
•     Understand the principles of the EU regulations on public procurement and how such regulations impact purchasing for care and purchasing of care.

•     Are able to reflect on the importance of purchasing in their own organisations so that they can collaborate, as a non-purchasing professional, with the purchasing department to contribute to the overall performance of their organisation.

column1: Health care providers are dependent on suppliers for the production and delivery of the services they provide to their customers. In the same vein, health care financers (such as health insurers) are dependent on the health care providers to supply health care services to their clients. In both cases, the purchasing function has the responsibility to secure external inputs (goods, services, knowledge, people) from the suppliers against the best possible conditions.

In the health care supply chain, we distinguish between purchasing of health care and purchasing for health care. When we speak of purchasing of health care, the health care is the product that is purchased (e.g., care or cure purchased by health insurers). When we speak of purchasing for health care, we are looking at a broad spectrum of goods and services needed by health care providers, such as medical devices, temporary labor, catering, and much more. Health care represents a considerable portion of public (and private) spending, and therefore, various entities (such as the WHO, as well as the Dutch NZa and RVS) are pointing towards professional purchasing management as a possible contributor to cost containment, quality improvement, innovation, and productivity enhancement in the health care sector.
In this course, we connect management theory in the area of purchasing and supply management to the specific characteristics of the health care sector.

column1: Het vak Heffingen lokale overheden behandelt de gemeentelijke belastingen en retributies en plaatst dit specialistische vakgebied in perspectief ten opzichte van het gehele fiscale stelsel.

Daarbij is, naast kennis van de lokale belastingen, die veelal een geheel eigen karakter hebben, ook inzicht in de structuur van dit nog steeds groeiende belastinggebied van belang. De verbondenheid van de belastingverordeningen dient kritisch te kunnen worden beoordeeld. Gegeven de veelvuldige wijzigingen (ook in dit deel van het belastingrecht) dient inzicht te worden verkregen in de materiële gevolgen van implementatie van nieuwe regelgeving, waaronder het steeds bredere gebruik van de WOZ-waarde, bijvoorbeeld in de inkomstenbelasting en in de vennootschapsbelasting (de beperking van de afschrijving op gebouwen ingevolge de Wet Werken aan Winst).

Heffingen lokale overheden richt zich op een uitwerking van diverse belastingen en rechten die gemeenten, provincies en waterschappen heffen, alsmede op de Wet waardering onroerende zaken, haar uitvoeringsregels en de taxatiemethoden.
Daarnaast komt de toepassing van rechtsbeginselen in ruime mate aan bod, zoals de werking van het gelijkheidsbeginsel en het evenredigheidsbeginsel.</body>

column1: The fashion industry is a paradigmatic sector of post-industrial economies, whose products increasingly rely on symbolic and aesthetic considerations as well as on local heritage and specificities. The fashion industry revolves around a myriad of key locations around the world, yet this has been the case for an extended period of time. A polycentric geography of fashion emerged, integrating traditional supply chains with digital technologies. Some luxury brands, such as Louis Vuitton, are even engaging with blockchain to prove the authenticity of their products. Topics covered in the course, among others: place, space and heritage in the fashion industry, storytelling, craftsmanship, temporary fashion clusters, and policies for fashion. In particular, storytelling appears to be an important tool for the fashion industry due to the necessity to differentiate the various products or brands and to add emotional value to them. Heritage and tradition are at the core of storytelling. Even new fashion products and brands are imbued with a historical flavor and sense of legendary quality, with the help of storytelling and revived craftsmanship. Given the rise of sustainability concerns, storytelling and craftsmanship, and in general heritage, are gaining momentum for the fashion industry and other creative industries too.
·         The  maximum  number of students  is 30.

·         A maximum number of 10 students will be accepted from the MA Cultural Economics and Entrepreneurship and MA Place, Culture and Tourism. It is not allowed to follow Heritage and Fashion together with Economics of Fashion, Design and Architecture.

column1: Het moderne subject als autonoom en rationeel individu werd geboren in de gedachten van Descartes en Kant, zo wordt beweerd. Maar tijdens de 20e eeuw tot heden trekken veel filosofen de vrijheid, rationaliteit en coherentie van het subject in twijfel. Is het subject wel zo autonoom en vrij als het meent te zijn? Is het wel wat het denkt dat het is? In welke mate zijn we bepaald door de maatschappelijke, culturele, economische en politieke aard?

In deze cursus zullen we nagaan hoe het huidige beeld van de mens als een autonoom, rationeel individu zich heeft ontwikkeld en op welke grenzen het stuit. We bespreken klassieke teksten uit de subjectfilosofie en analyseren de kritiek aan deze posities van denkers uit de 20e en 21e eeuw waaronder Freud, Nietzsche, Sartre, De Beauvoir, Lacan en Žižek. Daarbij zal duidelijk worden dat niet enkel het concept van het subject, maar ook het filosofische denken zelf altijd ingebed ligt in omstandigheden van maatschappelijke, culturele en politieke aard en dat die elkaar over en weer beïnvloeden.

column1: De werkcolleges zijn verplicht voor voltijdstudenten Filosofie.

Zij/hij geeft een onderbouwde redenering over de deugdelijkheid van de genoemde kritiekpunten (die gericht zijn tegen het concept van een autonoom een rationeel subject).

column1: This course offers an overview of how to find, analyse and use primary, secondary and tertiary sources for historical research. Students will learn how they can find and evaluate these sources using traditional resources, such as bibliographies, book reviews and reference works, but they also  have  to  familiarise  themselves  with new research methods  such as  online  databases  and Internet sources. Students  not only  learn how to find these sources, they  also acquire  the  skills  to  organise  and evaluate  all this  information. They can find  this  information on the  internet,  but they  also  have  to  visit libraries  and archives  to  collect the most relevant data for their research. Students will be introduced to historiographical debates and will learn how to identify debates relevant to their research. They will also learn to write a structural analysis of these historiographical debates.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Students will learn how scholarly information is communicated and how they have to credit other academics’ work in their research. They can find and evaluate primary, secondary and tertiary sources, and identify and use different types of sources in historical research. Students  will be able to find relevant source material in libraries, archives and on the internet, using digital tools for historical research. Students will learn how to write a structural analysis and to analyse historiographical debates.

column1: Leaders are key players in organizational functioning because they critically affect the people they work with—both inside and outside of their organization. Leaders are in a unique position to mobilise employees to excel and contribute to the organisation’s mission and vision. At the same time, however, they may also be a primary source of conflict and demotivation. Understanding what makes for high performance leadership as well as where leadership can go wrong, therefore, is of critical importance to any aspiring leader; and in particular for HR professionals who may come to take the lead of the HR organization, as well as facilitate the process of leadership in their organization.

In this course, we address one key question: “what makes an effective leader?” from a range of different theoretical perspectives (e.g., social identity, visionary leadership) and cast in the context of contemporary workplace trends (e.g., demographic change, digitization). Through a sequence of readings, lectures, cases, and experiential exercises, students learn to understand and apply state-of-the-art leadership theories, analyse and evaluate the determinants of leadership successes and failures, as well as apply these learnings to make recommendations for real-world leadership challenges.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Upon completion of the course, you should be able to:
1. Understand and apply the state-of-the art theories in leadership (i.e., vision communication, identity-based leadership)
2. Analyze and evaluate the determinants of leadership successes and failure
3. Communicate theoretically sound and practically relevant recommendations for “better” leadership in a persuasive manner
4. Practice and develop your leadership through self-awareness, application, and reflection.

column1: The discipline of sociology was established during (and to make sense of) the process of modernisation. A core characteristic of modernisation is rapid social change, and sociology theorises and studies such changes by comparing traditional societies to modern societies. The perspectives that were developed and the topics addressed by the founders of the discipline are still relevant today, because they regard issues as socioeconomic inequality, social order and deviance, the role of religion and ideology, gender relations, what it means to live in an urbanised world, the relation of individuals with society. In this course we learn about these classic perspectives by looking at contemporary societies. We will learn to apply the ‘sociological imagination’ to everyday life as well as study the classic sociological questions using present-day cases. Assessment consists of a final exam and an essay.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

After this course, students will be able to describe and apply the three most important sociological perspectives (functionalism, conflict sociology, symbolic interactionism) to issues such as modernization, inequality, cohesion and individualization.

In addition, students are able to reproduce the meaning of and theory formation around the following key concepts: Scientific paradigms; Identity performance; Political distrust; Gender segregation in the labour market; Deviance and social problems; Religion and Atheism; Sociology of Globalization.</body>

column1: The past is not simply gone. It permeates people's lives through memory and imagination, and offers an orientation in time. Telling stories about what happened in the past plays a key role in the construction of personal and collective identities. Creating a historical narrative through emplotment means establishing a sequence of selected historical events that makes the events meaningful to a contemporary audience in a specific way. Tragic stories of historical injustice fuel calls for reparations or for emancipation. Governments go to great lengths to control historical narration and interpretation to legitimize the political entities they govern, or to legitimize their policies. Also individuals historicize their own lives through narration in order to deal with expected and unexpected challenges and opportunities.

A central concept to understand these and similar processes is historical culture. The concept refers to historical narratives and performances, to the infrastructure of the historical field which makes it possible for people to deal with past, and to different conceptions of history that enable historical imagination.

This course provides theoretical reflection on historical culture and discusses methods, such as the use of various time concepts, and the making of narrative plotlines. We will study several cases, such as analysing the narrative scripts of historical reconciliation committees, comparing the politics of descent in political speeches, and the politics of historical periodization.

• Students can defend a theoretically and empirically informed position in contemporary memory debates

column1: Images can have a major mobilizing force. For instance, cartoons of a lazy stadholder William V encouraged the Dutch patriots to rebel against the Orangist family; and in the late 1960s, photo's about the Vietnam war in   the  newspapers  triggered  mass  protests  against  the  American  government.  The same goes for representations of a shared, contested, or imagined past. These images of the past can evoke feelings of recognition, resistance or nostalgia, and can be used to educate, entertain, commemorate, unite, or to mobilize people.

This course focuses on the process of historical representation  and imagination since the late 18th century, as well als on the  contents, narrative,  functions and  impact of historical representations. We will discuss some interesting case-studies in which we apply the concepts from the literature. Students will elaborate on the concepts and their applications in the form of written work and a group presentation.</body>

column1: Students acquire knowledge about the process of representing and imagining the past in different contexts and media, such as monuments, exhibitions, commemorations, and historical re-enactments. They can contextualize and critically assess these images of the past in view of its functions for specific communities. They are capable to produce written papers and oral presentations on relevant topics of this course, based on the discussed concepts.

column1: The Research Workshop extends across terms 2 to 4 , preparing the students for writing their master’s thesis and guiding the writing process. This workshop comprises all phases, from writing the thesis to presenting the final result. Students choose their own research subjects within the broad overall theme of the Research Workshop. A thesis market is organized before the start of term 2, where after students select one of the Research Workshops and research themes on offer. Every Research Workshop is structured in the same way:
-  discussion of literature as an introduction to the theme
-  one-on-one progress meetings with thesis supervisor
-  critical discussion of the research proposals
-  discussion of and information on possible research methods
-  discussion of case studies and other work in progress
-  one-on-one progress meetings with thesis supervisor
-  discussion of case studies and other work in progress
-  one-on-one progress meetings with thesis supervisor
-  presentation of the thesis research at master conference in june 2017
The final grade will be determined at the end of term 4 .

The term Creative Industries is a relatively recent concept coined in the late 1990s by new labour in Britain. Ever since this contested concept has evolved into an important policy instrument of national and local governments, the European Union, and United Nations, as well as a lively academic discourse. The workshop aims to historicize the concept and explore the historical roots of the creative industries and aims to analyse different sectors of the industry, including fashion, art markets, film, radio, television, music, design, theatre, tourism and video games. Furthermore, this course looks at innovations within large and small firms and networks across a range of industries. It explores the role of institutions and organizations, in particular governments or similar gatekeeping structures, and the diversity of innovation processes and across different sectors of the economy in the long twentieth century. Finally, it focuses on the effects of innovation and creativity on economic growth, international competitiveness, and employment. Different theoretical approaches emphasising cultural, national, regional, local, and firm-based factors, will be explored and applied to case studies selected by the students.
Further information at the Thesis Market in October

column1: This course starts with an overview of the major founders of the social sciences (Adam Smith, Karl Marx, Emile Durkheim and Max Weber). These early social scientists assume that the rise of modernity around 1800 was a milestone in world history. They believe that early modern society was profoundly transformed by industrialisation, secularisation, democratisation and urbanisation. This particular view on historical developments is heavily criticised by historians, because of its Eurocentric, deterministic and teleological approach. However, these theories still offer an interesting starting-point for historical research, because modernisation theories laid the foundation of our modern, western self-awareness and is still frequently used to explain global historical developments. Some of the twentieth-century elaborations of these early social theories are discussed in this course. A critical reflection on current developments is also part of this course.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Until the 19th century trade was additional. Production focused on local consumption. The Industrial Revolution resulted in the use of mineral raw materials that could not locally be produced. Consequently, trade became more intense. At the end of the 19th century, the then for substantial parts colonialized countries of the Southern hemisphere supplied the West with raw materials. After World War II trade became more and more trade in diversified industrial products among the Western countries, but from the 1970s on, outsourcing and a change in policy in the South, resulted in a complete change not just of trade, but even of industrial production. The splitting up of the chains of production over a number of localities, often organized by multinational companies, not just caused an enormous increase of trade, but also in a huge growth of industrial production in previously backwards, and therefore low-wage areas. Consequently, trade grew again faster than production. The theories of international economic relations, from the ideas of Ricardo, Heckscher and Ohlin, Stolper and Samuelson, till the concepts of Krugman, the ideas on monetary policy, on international finance and on political interference in international economic relations will be discussed to see whether these can explain developments.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

·        Students can explain that in the 19th and 20th century international trade grew much faster than the global economy, that trade and economic growth are related and how the period of the World Wars and the Great Depression undermined this development, and so international trade.
·        As a consequence, they can recognize the results of political interference in international economic developments. From the 1970s, however, economic globalization recovered.

Students can interpret the general development in international trade in the last two centuries, using some basic theoretical concepts on economic trade, open-economy macro-economics, monetary relations, stable and floating currency rates, FDIs.

column1: In the early modern period, Western societies set their first steps towards modernity. In this process, they ultimately set off on a path diverging from the rest of the world. Most historians will agree on this part of the story, but it is still under debate how, why and when this divergence started. Did it    start with the American war of independence, the French Revolution and the Industrial Revolution or had the wheels of change already been set in motion long before? Did Europe feel born again as it set out to discover the unknown after the Plague? Were the religious 'dark-ages' eventually  enlightened by the Renaissance and reason? And to what extent did international trade provide the inspiration for and precede industrialisation? During this course, it will be critically assessed whether these changes were indigenous to Europe or should be viewed just as much as a result of Europe’s interaction with the rest of the world. In the lectures and tutorials, we will ask ourselves the question if historians have too easily projected their view of the world today on the past, instead of seeing early modern societies as different and unique in their own right.

column1: Lectures/seminars provide a general overview of the history of economics, with more detailed analysis of particular issues and problems, the precise coverage sometimes being varied to reflect the interests of those taking the course each year. Students are expected to read recommended materials beforehand, so that the lectures can focus on a discussion of the readings.

Topics likely to be covered (subject to students’ interests) include: Adam Smith, the market and trade; The Marginal Revolution – and “neoclassical” economics; Keynes, and the Keynesian Revolution; The rise of mathematical economics; The 1970s and after; Economics and other social sciences; Economists on method; Ethics and Welfare; Economists and ideology (and specific institutions).

Readings are selected to introduce students to a range of approaches to the subject. For example, Adam Smith is used to show how reading an economist through the lens of modern economics may be to impose ideas foreign to his or her thought; the lecture on Keynes introduces the idea of approaching the history of economics through an economist’s biography. Subsequent lectures give examples of work that debunks myths and which shows how changing philosophical presuppositions can change the way economic arguments are constructed.</body>

4) Explain, using one or more examples, how the historian’s perspective on episodes in the history of economics may differ from that of a modern economist.</body>

<body>From the middle of the eighteenth century, the industrial revolution, the spread of Enlightenment ideas and the rise of Romanticism, and the political revolutions in America and France created a structural transformation of Western Europe. A core notion that emerged, and that will serve as our central theme, is the contested idea of progress: the belief that humans are able to understand the world and improve it on the basis of that understanding. Each week we will focus on a specific theme that illustrates this basic idea and its critics. The first week is devoted to the rise of the new interventionist state from Napoleonic France on, the beginning of what would later be called the welfare state. During the second week we will study class conflicts in the nineteenth century, in connection with the increasing internationalization of the economy. Week three is devoted to the crisis of democracies during the interwar period, with a focus on the rise of fascism. In week four we will study the making of the modern material environment, especially the world-wide impact of modernist architecture, design, and city planning.</body>

column1: Week 1. In intellectual history, few areas have recently been the subject of such intense scrutiny as the history of political thought. During the first week/part of this course the so-called ‘Cambridge School’ will be discussed. Established by eminent practising historians such as Quentin Skinner, J.G.A. Pocock, and John Dunn, it rose to prominence during the 1960s and 1970s, inspiring intellectual historians far beyond political theory.

Week 2. With his enormously influential political philosophy, Plato (c. 427-347) tried to solve the problem of conflicting interests of different parts of society. We will how his quest for harmony produced a detailed vision of an ideal society in The Republic; and we will discuss whether this vision entailed a totalitarian nightmare. Aristotle’s political philosophy revolves around the notion of man as a political animal who needs the political entity of the polis (city-state) in order to realise a happy and virtuous life; we will study Aristotle’s ideas for the best form of government and we will also critically examine his arguments for the inclusion and exclusion for certain specific groups.

Week 3. Though not very well-known for his political standpoints, Desiderius Erasmus’ Philosophy of Christ would form the basis of a standpoint on the ideal society that shares many aspects with what is understood by the rule of law in ‘free’ societies today. His moral conception of politics contrasts sharply to what we find in his friend Thomas More’s famous book on Utopia. Both positions and their intricate interdependence will be addressed. Without any doubt the best-known and most notorious work of the Italian humanist and philosopher Niccolò Machiavelli (1469-1527) is Il Principe (The Prince), first published in 1513. Notorious, because The Prince can be interpreted as a manual for would-be dictators whose goal is to attain and maintain power at all cost. Less notorious and famous, but certainly not less interesting is Machiavelli’s later more elaborate work, especially his Discourses on Livy (1531), where the classical history of ancient Rome forms the background stage of a discussion on how to form and maintain a republic. By comparing both works the students will learn about the basic principles of Machiavelli’s political philosophy.

Week 4. In the 19th century J.S. Mill (1806-1873) is the forefather of modern liberalism and feminism. According to On Liberty (1859) the greatest threat to personal liberty is no longer the state as in classic liberalism, but ‘public opinion’, which enforces conformity. Karl Marx (1818-1883) is the source of both social-democracy and communism. In the Communist Manifesto (1848) he outlines a ‘materialist’ theory of society, which sees society not as an integrated whole, but as a contingent set of conflicting groups (classes), and he links society to economy.

column1: This course centers around a small question: what is order? Surely one could answer order is a normative societal framework, or, less formal, the outlines of the way humans organize their living together. But where do these outlines, or norms, reside? In authority and power, in institutions – ‘the state’ has shaped our lives profoundly over the past two centuries or –, in laws, or in our minds? Or do rather customs, shared history, identity or culture make up our social fabric? As one may expect, it is not either or. All these elements together constitute public ‘order’, in an often complicated interplay.

Overlooking a large time-span, this course goes back deep into the Middle Ages to cover the development of order. It seeks the roots of our modern conceptions of society, looking at the interaction between the ‘soft side’ – culture, identity, thought – and the ‘hard side’: institutions and laws. Conflict will be at the center of attention, since especially during wars, revolts and revolutions concepts of society are ‘energized’ as they are used to challenge or defend existing order. Put differently, this course treats ‘order’ as a ‘political argument’, as used through the centuries: from Aquinas and Erasmus to Roussseau and Durkheim. During the course, representation of power in art, architecture and literature shall be given much attention. These conveyed and visualised underlying conceptions of order and were used to raise support and get ‘order’ into people’s heads. Students will also themselve interpret an artwork in a paper.

The course History of Western Arts and Culture provides a historical and chronological overview of Western art and culture from the late Middle Ages until the 21st century. Students get acquainted with the major developments in the visual arts, architecture, music, and literature from this period, against a historical background. It is demonstrated how the highlights from these disciplines originate from, reflect, and shape the socio-cultural context of their time, and how these historical developments continue to have their effects on contemporary culture.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

History of Western Arts and Culture is intended for first-year students of the International Bachelor Arts and Culture Studies/Algemene Cultuurwetenschappen. The aim is to provide them with a historical and versatile foundation for their further studies. Students will acquire a historical overview of the main developments and trends in Western art and culture, and gain insight into how the various disciplines (visual arts, literature, architecture and music) are interrelated.  Furthermore, students will gain insight into the way in which art comes from, reflects on, and at the same time shapes the socio-cultural context of its time. Finally, students will acquire knowledge on how the position of the artist in relation to fellow artists, clients and the public has developed historically.

This course will provide an introduction to the history of the Dutch and European art markets, and the way the art trade functions as an intermediary between artist and audience. Various aspects dealing with the production, distribution and consumption of art will be discussed. For instance the development and growing importance of art auctions from the seventeenth century until the present will be examined in detail, as well as other more recent developments such as the impact of new media on the art market.

History and memory are analytically distinct, but overlapping concepts. The significance of both concepts is closely related to the emergence of nation states and their colonial empires, and to the professionalization of the pursuit of history. In this course we discuss the relationship between history and memory, and how this relationship has changed over time due to fundamental changes in society, such as the French Revolution, the emergence of mass culture, secularization, two world wars, new media, globalization, and transformations in historical scholarship. We will also study specific applications of these concepts in examples of (popular) historical culture, such as the construction of the nation state, heritage and public history.</body>

column1: De psychologie is een breed vak met verschillende subdisciplines, zoals sociale psychologie, persoonlijkheidspsychologie en ontwikkelingspsychologie. Tijdens deze minor maken studenten kennis met een aantal psychologische fenomenen uit het leven van alledag. Voorbeelden van vragen die aan bod komen zijn: hoe betrouwbaar is ons geheugen? Heeft het zin om hard na te denken, of kun je beter op je intuïtie vertrouwen? Waarom wordt de ene persoon topsporter en de andere niet? Wat is normaal en abnormaal?

Deelnemers aan deze minor krijgen een bloemlezing van onderwerpen uit de psychologie voorgeschoteld (denk aan geheugen, persoonlijkheid en ontwikkeling). Verder wordt een historische overzicht van het vakgebied gegeven. Ook wordt aandacht besteed aan de methodologie van de wetenschappelijke psychologie. Aan het eind van de minor zal de deelnemer onderscheid kunnen maken tussen wetenschappelijke kennis en psychologische huis-tuin-en-keuken inzichten.
De minor bestaat uit colleges en werkgroepen. Een afsluitende toets is de basis voor het eindcijfer. Na de minor vindt er een toetsinzage plaats.
De literatuur is nog niet bekend. Bedenk dat veel psychologische literatuur Engelstalig is.

We humans have an irresistible urge to explain our own and others’ behaviour, to attribute it to some causes and therefore, to make it seems orderly, predictable and controllable. Why do we behave, think, and feel as we do in social situations? How are our thoughts, feelings and behaviours shaped by others? How do we make sense of our social world and how do we become social? How do we see ourselves? These are the type of questions that the course Man & Society seeks to address. Obviously, a huge number of variables play a role in answering these questions and many disciplines employ scientific techniques to answer these questions. However, in this course we will try to answer these questions from a socio-psychological perspective and use quantitative research to investigate how and why certain (socio-psychological) behaviours occurred.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course deals with an important and relevant area of psychology, the social psychology. Social psychology is the scientific field that seeks to understand the nature and causes of individual behaviour in social situations. Social psychologists are interested in underlying social and cognitive processes as they are in overt behaviour. The central theme of social psychology is how people understand and interact with each other.
Upon completion of this course, students should be able to:

column2: • Discuss the history and research methods of social psychology;
• Distinguish between cultures regarding the processes that underlie our thought, behaviour, and feelings in social situations;
• Apply theoretical concepts of this course in a more practical manner;
• Identify the components of the self and self-schemas;
• Define attitudes and how they develop and change;
• Explain the theories and dynamics of group formation: social categorization and social identity;
• Understand the antecedents and consequences of stereotyping, prejudice, racism, discrimination, and genocide;
• Describe evolutionary approaches to helping others and the bystander effect;
• Understand the way people attach meaning to other’s and their own behavior;
• Explain the theories of attraction and romantic relationships;
• Write a scientifically sound research paper on a particular subtopic from social psychology.

column1: The study of anatomy (and morphology) is crucial in understanding how multiple tissue types and organ systems are organised in multicellular organisms, and how they interact. Moreover, it is not possible to understand how such organisms ‘work’ (as studied in physiology) without having a fundamental anatomical knowledge. Clearly, this knowledge is also vital when studying the nature of a disease (pathology) as well as the biological mechanisms that lead to disease (pathogenesis).

In this course, we will focus on the anatomy of humans. You will learn the exact location, three-dimensional orientation and morphology of all major human body parts, and you will learn the correct anatomical language that is required to describe these parts. Particular attention will be given to the cardiovascular, respiratory, gastrointestinal, nervous, and musculoskeletal systems. The course is designed in tight collaboration with the Erasmus MC, and consists of expert lectures, interactive tutorials, and dissection room practicals, which ensure that you will get a practical, hands-on learning experience.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • obtain a general understanding of the use and importance of general anatomical nomenclature (in Latin and/or English);
• learn to actively use the terms in the anatomy checklist to describe the basic anatomy of the bony skeleton and its joints;
• be able to relate the dermal and musculoskeletal system of the extremities to its nervous innervation;
• be able to explain how musculoskeletal system allows the movement and stability of the human body;
• be able to identify and describe the basic anatomy and functional properties of the anatomy of the thorax;
• learn how to describe the main characteristics of the human blood circulation and name the main arteries and veins of the human body;
• be able to identify and describe all the abdominal and pelvic organs and know where they are located in the abdominal and pelvic cavity, respectively;
• learn the basic functional anatomy of the human nervous system and head and neck structures.

column1: Human physiology studies how cells, tissues, organs and organ systems function in a healthy human body in response to internal and environmental changes. An important focus point of this course is homeostasis, i.e. the maintenance of the steady state of the body within the narrow ranges that are compatible with life. You will learn that homeostasis is regulated at multiple levels, from the cellular to the organismal level. To understand these levels of regulation, it is crucial to study the structure and function of different organs in the human body. In this course, we will study the role of the central and peripheral nervous system in human physiology, and you will learn about the circulatory system, the respiratory system, the musculoskeletal system, digestive system, urinary system, and the endocrine system under normal circumstances. In addition, we will explore what might happen with these systems in unusual situations, for instance in space.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The physiology of systems under scrutiny include the integumentary system, the nervous system, the circulatory system, the respiratory system, the musculoskeletal system, digestive system, renal system, and the endocrine system. The immune system will be studied in detail in Quad 4, 200-level course, 'Micro- and immunobiology', and is therefore not a focus within this course.
Learning objectives regarding the biological systems under study include:

column2: • Be able to recognize different histological tissue samples from one another.
• Be able to describe the structure and identify characteristics of the organs’ tissues and relate them to their functioning.
• Understand how these vital parameters are regulated/ kept constant under normal and extraordinary circumstances (e.g., microgravity, high altitudes, cold temperatures).
• Be able to make and present a scientific poster in a clear and attractive way.

column4: This module focuses on the strategic level of HRM: how can we use HRM practices to achieve long term viability for (public) organizations. Notwithstanding this strategic orientation, the importance of ‘tactical’ HRM (e.g. which HRM practices ‘work’ and why) will be also dealt with. The first part of the module will discuss the theoretical background of strategic HR: what is it and why is it important? In

the second part several more concrete themes (e.g. training, work design, motivation, leadership) will addressed using recent academic literature. Although the focus will be on ‘general mechanisms’, students will be asked in this part to reflect on the usability of these mechanisms in the context of a developing country. This reflection will be supported by a discussion of several academic articles about HRM related themes in developing countries.

column1: In many industries, the personnel – or the Human Resources – of an organization are one of the most vital factors shaping an organization’s success or failure. Decisions that involve the hiring, training, job assignments, or the separation of employees have far-reaching consequences. These consequences do not only involve financial gains or losses and have potential legal implications for the organization but also affect individuals and their motivation and ability to be productive and satisfied.

This course offers you an evidence-based perspective on the main challenges in Human Resource Management. We begin by examining the conceptual foundations of Human Resource Management, including the design of jobs and work processes, and the conditions under which work is satisfying and engaging. We then focus on the hiring process all the way from the human resource planning to sealing the deal with new hires and starting the socialization process. Building on this, a number of sessions deal with how one can achieve great results with the people within an organization by motivating and compensating their efforts, measuring their performance, as well as training and developing them for current and future tasks. Finally, we will consider how to manage employee’s voluntary and involuntary exit from organizations. By the end of the course, you will have a deep understanding of- and basic hands-on experience regarding the most important HR practices considering the empirical evidence that supports or discourages their use.

We begin by examining the conceptual foundations of HRM, including the design of jobs and work processes, and the conditions under which work is satisfying and engaging. We then focus on the hiring process all the way from human resource planning to sealing the deal with new hires and starting the socialisation process. Building on this, we deal with how one can achieve great results with the people within an organization by motivating and rewarding their efforts, measuring their performance, as well as training and developing them for current and future tasks. Finally, we will consider how to manage employees’ voluntary and involuntary exit from organizations.

By the end of the course, you will have a deep understanding of and basic hands-on experience with the most important HR practices in light of empirical evidence that supports or discourages their use.  You will have learned to look beyond short-term financial gains for the organization when making decisions that affect people in organizations, but also have a thorough understanding of evidence-based guidelines on employee well-being, job satisfaction, and fairness. column1: Human Resource Management (HRM) gaat er vanuit dat de mens een belangrijke bron is voor organisatiesucces en heeft daarom als doel het personeelsmanagement zo goed mogelijk te laten verlopen. Hoewel dit geldt voor HRM in alle organisaties, kent HRM in publieke organisaties een aantal specifieke uitdagingen en toepassingen.

In deze module wordt daarom ingegaan op actuele thema’s binnen HRM in de publieke sector zoals horizontaal management, diversiteit en inclusie, werknemers mobiliteit en werkgeluk. Deze thema’s hebben gemeenschappelijk dat ze hoog op de agenda van wetenschappers en beleidsmakers staan. In de hoorcolleges wordt dan ook gebruik gemaakt van actuele voorbeelden en recente literatuur.

De literatuur voor dit vak bestaat uit wetenschappelijke artikelen die via Canvas te verkrijgen zijn. Er wordt van u verwacht dat u voorafgaand aan het hoorcollege de aangewezen artikelen leest. Het is daarnaast mogelijk om voorafgaand aan ieder hoorcollege een individuele opdracht in te leveren. Door deze individuele opdrachten met een voldoende af te ronden kunt u 20% van het eindcijfer behalen, en hoeft u minder vragen te beantwoorden op het take-home tentamen.

column1: Most organizations today collect a wealth of data that could help improve organizational outcomes. Still, only few succeed in using this data successfully. The phenomenon of Human Resource (HR) Analytics and the respective field(s) of research could potentially fill this void. HR Analytics gained traction in recent years as a movement that could let the HR profession evolve. Contrasting with the ""soft” approach that was long associated with the HR, HR Analytics seeks to add value to the organization by leveraging analytical processes, a broad range of statistical techniques, and novel data sources.

In this course, we learn how to use HR data and HR Analytics to improve business outcomes and make better HR decisions. The overarching question of the course is how can organizations use data to better understand organizational processes? Through a sequence of readings, lectures, and experiential exercises, we learn what questions to ask, how to determine which methods to use, we will discuss the strengths and weaknesses of different research designs, we will analyze several (applied) datasets during the lab sessions and we will discuss what organizations could learn from the results of these analyses. We will be studying the following six topics each covered by a specialist: recruitment & diversity, recruitment & personality, HRM practices & organizational outcomes, employability, gender and leadership and careers.
To prepare for the meeting you are expected to read three research articles in advance. These can be downloaded via your university library. Examples of articles that will be covered are:
Flory, J. A., Leibbrandt, A., Rott, C., & Stoddard, O. (2021). Increasing workplace diversity: Evidence from a recruiting experiment at a Fortune 500 company. Journal of Human Resources, 0518-9489R1.
Hambrick, D. & C., & Mason, P. A. (1984). Upper echelons: The organization as a reflection of its top managers. Academy of Management Review, 9(2), 193-206.
Oostrom, J. K., de Vries, R. E., & De Wit, M. (2019). Development and validation of a HEXACO situational judgment test. Human Performance, 32(1), 1-29.
Peccei, R., & Van De Voorde, K. (2019). Human resource management–well‐being–performance research revisited: Past, present, and future. Human Resource Management Journal, 29(4), 539-563.

column1: This course addresses the various legal instruments and monitoring/enforcement mechanisms for the international protection of human rights, placing emphasis on the United Nations and its various organs, as well as regional organizations (with a main focus on the Council of Europe and its European Convention on Human Rights). After a brief but intensive study of the key underlying doctrinal debates in human rights and its connection to international law, students will comprehensively examine the principal international human rights treaties, enforcement systems, and illustrative case law.

The different instruments and protection mechanisms are explored in relation to contemporary debates regarding the concept, scope, development and – obstacles to the actual – enforcement of human rights.

The course aims at enabling students to identify the relevant actors, instruments and monitoring/enforcement mechanisms for the international protection of human rights. Furthermore, students successfully completing this course will be able to analyse recent trends and developments in the context of that framework and critically assess different points of view in relation to the application and interpretation of human rights. Students will also train their analytical, writing and debating skills by participating in the compulsory Seminars.
Accordingly, students successfully completing this course will be able to:
-    Independently analyse and assess, in the context of broader public international law, human rights treaty law;
-    Independently analyse and assess, in the context of broader public international law, legal problem statements pertaining to the implementation or enforcement of international human rights law;
-    Develop ways, in cooperation with others, of addressing human rights problem statements with profound societal ramifications;

-    Independently present, in both oral (viz., in the form of moot court pleadings) and written (viz., in the form of written memorials) form, the results of academic research as well as legal advice, both to other lawyers and to a non-legally trained audience.</body>

column1: In de meeste sectoren is het effectief managen van personeel – Human Resource Management (HR/HRM) – een bepalende factor voor het succes of het falen van de organisatie. Beslissingen over werving, training, taakstelling, beloning en ontslag hebben namelijk verstrekkende gevolgen. Ze hebben niet alleen betrekking op het economisch welvaren van de organisatie of het juridisch kader, maar vooral ook op mensen en hun motivatie, welzijn en productiviteit.

Dit vak biedt een evidence-based perspectief op de belangrijkste uitdagingen in Human Resource Management. We beginnen met het onderzoeken van de conceptuele basis van Human Resource Management, inclusief het ontwerp van banen en werkprocessen en de voorwaarden waaronder werk bevredigend en boeiend is. Vervolgens richten we ons op het wervingsproces, van de personeelsplanning tot het aannemen van nieuwe medewerkers en het starten van het socialisatieproces. Hierop voortbouwend hoe we prestaties meten, hoe bedrijven goede resultaten kunnen bereiken door hun personeel te motiveren en te betalen voor hun inspanningen en hoe de opleiding en de ontwikkeling voor huidige en toekomstige taken vorm kan krijgen. Ten slotte gaan we na hoe we het vrijwillig en onvrijwillig verlaten van organisaties door werknemers kunnen beheren.

Het is de bedoeling dat je aan het eind van dit vak theoretisch inzicht hebt verworven in de belangrijkste HRM-praktijken en ze tegelijk ook op hun praktijkwaarde kunt beoordelen. Onze aandacht gaat daarbij in het bijzonder uit naar hoe wetenschappelijke onderzoeksresultaten deze HR-praktijken ondersteunen dan wel ontkrachten.

column1: In modern society it has become more difficult to address complex problems through broad institutional measures. Issues such as obesity, viral transmission, and global warming cannot be solved by rough supply-side measures such as placing taxes on sugar, restricting physical mobility, or limiting carbon emissions. In these situations real human change is needed to solve the problem of suboptimal demand. For this to happen, there is a growing need to identify and address the needs and values of individuals and provide them with useful tools to optimize their behavior towards the common good of society.

At the same time, introduction of regulations such as the GDPR in Europe, and HIPAA in the United States place strong requirements on privacy protection and security making the collection and distribution of individual data more difficult. Individuals have become more privacy aware in recent years, especially in situations wherein personal information is misused towards the detriment of the individual (i.e. demographic profiling). The importance of protecting personal information increases even more as political stability and social equity are put under pressure.

This course seeks new ways to address complex problems by putting the human being at the center of the technical development process. Students will choose a current topic of interest and analyze human needs in this area. They will then use business process modeling techniques and technologies to develop human-centered processes which adhere to privacy-preserving standards. At the end of the course, students will be equipped with the tools and knowledge to innovate practical solutions for modern societal problems.</body>

column1: The objective of this class is to teach students how to develop human-centered processes to address complex societal issues. Students will engage in an iterative development process involving the input and feedback of users. Phases of development will involve the input of user stakeholders together with explanations of current privacy, data protection, and information architecture standards.
By the end of the class, students should be able to:

column2: • Identify a complex problem wherein individual behavior plays a key role
• Analyze the needs of a set of relevant stakeholder users
• Implement processes using workflow and decision engines
• Present implemented processes to stakeholder users and gather feedback for improvement
• Summarize findings in a comprehensive, yet succinct, report

column1: The first two decades of the 21st century have witnessed a considerable reduction of poverty and associated phenomena in countries previously labeled as “under-developed” countries. The rapid and widespread innovations, mostly enabled and  driven  by  Information  and  Communication Technologies (ICTs), have given rise to “Emerging Markets”, also known as “Emerging Economies”. More and more developing countries are making remarkable inroads into economic growth and some have even become global leaders in specific areas. The introduction of the Internet, followed by the advent of mobile telephony, has been instrumental in driving innovation in vital sectors such as education, healthcare, economic livelihood, and local entrepreneurship, to mention a few areas. ICT and Innovation scholars project not only more ICT-driven innovations in emerging markets, but also the transfer from those innovations into developed countries (reverse innovation).

This seminar offers students a critical, analytical, historical, and practical insight into the various ways in which Emerging Markets have been taking advantage of the development process to become central to the ICT-driven innovations. Students historically explores the transition from the previous approach, one that was mostly centred on international development policies, to the current home- grown, ICT-driven innovation approach to poverty alleviation. In this seminar, students get an insight into real-life ICT-driven innovations that involve various actors (e.g., local startups, NGOs, governments, multinationals) and in different areas and sectors. The seminar focuses on the following key areas: education (in the broader sense), healthcare, rural entrepreneurship (income- generating activities), economic livelihood, and banking (and related services). While exploring these areas, students are invited to go beyond the surface (the hype) to critically consider underlying concepts such as power, gender, sustainability, inclusiveness, and ethics.
Note: The course will be cancelled if there are less than 10 students. The maximum number of participants is 25. IBCoM students take priority over other students.

column1: How can information and communication technologies (ICTs) be used to create societal impact and promote social change? The advent of Interned-based communication, such as social media, online platforms and communities, has created new opportunities for organizations and businesses to mobilize large online crowds to exchange information, gain resources, obtain new skills and knowledge, and eventually achieve social change in sustainable development, health, environment, and the social sector. While there are several examples in academic research and practice of the use of technologies for social purposes, it is also important to develop a critical understanding of the effectiveness of these practices and their societal impact.

This course offers a unique combination of topics at the intersection of sociology and business information management to understand new organizational forms produced by ICTs and aiming at social change. We will analyze and discuss how ICTs can be used as a possible way to find solutions to some of the world’s most challenging social problems across a range of domains (e.g., social welfare, health, environment, education, sustainable development, activism). In addition, we will also critically analyze advantages and disadvantages of ICTs use for social purposes.
•    The driving motivation of this elective is to develop a critical understanding of and ability to design and evaluate the use of ICTs to solve relevant problems and issues of our society.
Practically, this course will offer insights about
•    How we, as citizens, can directly engage and collaborate in the solution of societal problems via an effective and responsible use of ICTs.
•    How organizations and businesses can make effective use ICTs for social purposes.

By studying cases from academic, empirical research on the use of technologies for social change, this course will also offer an opportunity to
5.    Understand the importance of conducting research with a societal impact by connecting the creation of knowledge with possible practical applications or solutions to social problems.
6.    Understand and reflect upon the use Big Data and computational methods to conduct research that is important for society.

column1: In a knowledge-based and innovation-driven business environment, managing ideas is an essential capability if an organization is to gain a sustainable competitive advantage. All innovations begin with ideas and managing these ideas is needed during the entire innovation process. Employees in any job and at any level of the organization can contribute to innovation with creative ideas. Thus idea management is important for everyone and at any moment.

This course takes place as part of the master in Management of Innovation. After general courses concerning innovation strategy and organization of innovation it is the first of a series of two courses that follow the temporal order innovation in the innovation funnel: Fuzzy front end (this course: idea generation, selection and communication), and Implementation (course 2: Innovation Implementation).

The course consists of a series of lectures, 3 assignments and an exam. The assignment concern stimulating idea generation (assignment 1 – groups assignment), conducting idea evaluation (assignment 2 – group assignment), and idea communication (assignment 3 – individual assignment). All assignments are worth 20% of the final grade. </body>

column1: <body>Today’s culture is a visual culture. Since the 1970s, the social sciences and the humanities have increasingly turned their attention to the many ways in which visual technologies and images have come to play a central role in the construction of the shared meanings, or mental representations, through which our social practices are structured. Images reproduce power relations as much as they can contest dominant ways of seeing, and thinking about, the world. In this course we will analyse representations of class, gender, race and sexuality that circulate in the media by discussing and applying various key texts and methodologies from the fields of media studies and cultural analysis. Students read foundational texts by authors such as Marshal McLuhan, Roland Barthes, Stuart Hall, and Laura Mulvey in a weekly seminar and apply various visual methodologies in order to analyse a self-selected set of images in our weekly workshop.</body>

column1: Does increasing legal retirement age maintain individuals longer at work? Does development aid raise economic growth? Do changes in schooling laws improve health? The answer to any of these questions requires valid methods to evaluate the impact of different interventions.

The objective of this course is to provide students with a set of theoretical and practical skills that will allow them to evaluate the causal impact of different policy interventions and social programs. The course will introduce students to a variety of econometric methods in impact evaluation and a set of reasoning skills to help them design an evaluation study and assess critically existing studies. Students will get hands-on experience with applying the techniques in Stata.
At the end of the course students will be able to:

column2: • Understand and apply a variety of impact evaluation methods
• Draw policy implications from impact evaluation research

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/93094,2020,Impact Evaluation,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['prof.dr. JLW van Kippersluis'],,Inhoud

Does a university degree raise your future wage? Does increasing the legal retirement age maintain individuals longer at work? Does restricting the bonuses of portfolio managers lead to less risk taking? Does development aid raise economic growth? Answering such questions requires a valid method of evaluating the effect of interventions.

In medicine one patient group is randomly assigned to a treatment while others receive a placebo. Identifying the effect of treatment is then relatively straightforward. In business, economics and social policy, such randomized experiments are often infeasible, unaffordable or considered unethical. Statistical methods must then be used to estimate the effect of an intervention relative to a counterfactual. This often calls for a great deal of creativity on the part of the analyst.

This course will give a non-technical overview of the intuition behind the most frequently applied evaluation methods in economics. The students will learn the required steps in a valid evaluation, the distinction between correlation and causal effects, the assumptions of different methods and in which situation each method can be used.

The main concepts are introduced in the first five weeks. The second part of the course is devoted to a group assignment, which will consist of a critical assessment of an existing evaluation, providing suggestions for improvement, and implementing these suggestions yourself. The students will hand-in a written report.</body>
